title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: In August, cargo traffic declined by 10.2% y-o-y, registering its steepest decline since Mar 19. Despite August’s strong pax traffic growth and load factors, we remain neutral on SINGAPORE AIRLINES (SGX:C6L) as yields could weaken if the economic environment deteriorates further.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Maintain HOLD. Target price: S$9.50. Suggested entry price: S$8.70-8.80.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: August’s cargo traffic registered the steepest decline since Mar 19, with cargo load factor falling 6ppt y-o-y.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Ytd FY20, cargo traffic has declined 5.9% y-o-y, which was marginally higher than our full-year estimate of -5.5% y-o-y. The decline in cargo traffic underscores heightened risk for the parent airline at the operating level. In general, we expect yield for air cargo to remain weak in the months ahead, as IATA report showed that 41% of surveyed airlines’ heads of cargo were expecting deteriorating cargo volume and yields in the next 12 months.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Ytd FY20, load factor was 58.2%, which is marginally lower than 1QFY20’s 58.7%. This bodes ill for Singapore Airlines’s cargo business in 2QFY20 as cargo revenue fell by S$44.6m in 1QFY20.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Underlying demand for pax traffic remains strong, but could be at the expense of yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Parent airline’s pax load factor improved by 1.5ppt y-o-y in August 19 as pax traffic increased 8.1% y-o-y, outpacing capacity growth.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Ytd FY20, pax traffic has risen by 8.5% y-o-y with pax load factor (PLF) rising by 1.2ppt. The improvement in PLF was broad-based across all route regions except for East Asia and the Americas. The key uncertainty is whether this was achieved on the back of weaker pax yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: In 1QFY20, pax yields rose 1% y-o-y and we have estimated a 1.1% y-o-y increase in FY20.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: SilkAir’s higher PLF of 81.2% in August could lower losses in 2QFY20.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: In 1QFY20, SilkAir incurred a S$16m loss with a 78.1% load factor while its breakeven load factor was 85.3%. Ytd 2QFY20, SilkAir has achieved an 80.6% load factor.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Scoot’s PLF improved for three consecutive months to 88.6%, the highest since May 19.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Load factors improved for West Asia and Rest of World, while East Asia declined as demand growth fell short of capacity expansion. In 1QFY20, Scoot reported a net loss of S$37m with a breakeven load factor of 96%.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Increased geo-political tensions in the Middle East have raised fuel price volatility and risks for SIA and its associates.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Singapore Airlines had effectively hedged 73% of its fuel requirements (70% on jet fuel; 5% on Brent) for the remaining nine months of FY20. Ytd FY20, jet fuel has averaged US$78/bbl, which is below our estimated average of US$83/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: We estimate that every US$1/bbl increase in fuel price from our base assumption would lower Singapore Airlines’s PBT by S$12.8m, net of fuel hedging. Our jet fuel price assumptions are maintained at US$83.4/bbl for FY20.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: A greater concern is the impact of higher jet fuel prices on Singapore Airlines’s airline associates, Vistara and Virgin Australia, which are struggling with profitability. We believe earnings for both will be negatively impacted if fuel prices remain elevated.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Remain neutral on SIA in an uncertain yield environment.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: OECD business confidence has been declining since 2018, while the CASS freight index has been declining for nine consecutive months. The data appears to suggest that the global economic environment could be slowing down. This could impact discretionary travel and yields as well as business travel.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: Similarly, the prospect of a near-term Brexit poses risks to Singapore Airlines’s profitability as demand for business class travel could be affected as a result of companies shifting operations out of UK and potentially lesser connecting flights from UK to other parts of Europe post-Brexit. London Heathrow-Singapore was Singapore Airlines’s most profitable route in FY19 according to industry authority, OAG.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: No change to our earnings estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng
arguments: We maintain our HOLD recommendation with our unchanged fair value of S$9.50. We continue to value Singapore Airlines on an SOTP basis, with the airline operations valued at 0.75x book value and SIA Engineering (SGX:S59) valued at S$2.55.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now
analyst: K Ajith  | David Lee Gao Peng

title: Singapore Airlines  - Double-digit Decline In Cargo Traffic Is A Key Negative, Even As Pax Traffic Remains Robust For Now

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SIA, SGX:C6L)’s July pax traffic growth and load factors are still robust, indicating strong underlying pax demand. We remain hopeful that the incremental pax revenue and profits could offset the decline in cargo profitability.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: SIA, meanwhile, is trading at a 4- year low P/B multiple of 0.7x but dividend yield is not compelling.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Maintain HOLD. Target price: S$9.50. Suggested entry price: S$8.70.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Parent airline continues to register high-single-digit traffic growth as pax load factor (PLF) stays flat in Jul 19.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Ytd in FY20, pax traffic has risen by 8.6% with load factors rising by 1ppt. This underscores strong underlying demand for travel. In July, load factors in the Europe sector remained high at 90%, which holds strong premium cabin load factors.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Load factors however were weak for East Asia, the Americas and South West Pacific in July and conversely, we estimate that back-end yields for these markets would have been soft. These regions accounted for 33%, 14% and 20% of total passenger revenue respectively for SIA in FY19.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Cargo traffic and load factors continued to decline, but in-line with our full-year estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: July’s 5.7% y-o-y cargo traffic decline was worse than 1QFY20’s 4.4% y-o-y decline. Load factor for Jul 19 was the lowest in more than 10 years, implying both declining demand and excess capacity. Ytd, cargo traffic has declined by 4.7%, while we have estimated a 5.5% decline.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: SilkAir’s higher PLF in July holds scope for lower losses for 2QFY20.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: SilkAir’s July PLF improved by 3.2ppt to 80% on the back of capacity reduction of 1.7% y-o-y. In 1QFY20, SilkAir incurred a S$16m loss on a load factor of 78.1%. If load factors sustain above 80% in 2QFY20, losses are likely to be lowered.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Scoot’s July PLF still stands strong at 86.9% despite flattish yoy change.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Load factors however were weak for West Asia and East Asia in July as demand growth fell short of capacity injection. The capacity expansion was partly due to the transfer of two new routes from SilkAir. Comparing to 1QFY20’s PLF of 86.1%, the higher July PLF suggests that the management has been effective in adjusting capacity in response to slowing pax demand.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Net trade-off between higher pax traffic and lower cargo traffic is still likely to register incremental revenue.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: In 1QFY20, parent airline revenue grew by S$260m on 9% y-o-y traffic growth, while cargo revenue declined by S$45m on a 4.4% y-o-y decline in traffic. While July’s pax traffic growth lagged 1QFY20’s, we believe that SIA will still be able to register incremental revenue for the period, provided yields do not deteriorate further.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Weak fuel prices could improve profitability.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Jet fuel price is trading near US$75/bbl and for ytd FY20, it has averaged US$79.5/bbl. The latter is lower than our full-year estimate of US$83.4/bbl. For the remaining 9 months, SIA had effectively hedged 73% of jet fuel requirements at US$76/bbl. For every US$5 decline in fuel price, SIA’s FY20 earnings would rise by S$78m, net of fuel hedging.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: No change to our earnings estimates

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: Although SIA’s P/B (excluding SIA Engineering (SGX:S59)) is currently at a 4-year low of 0.7x, its relatively low dividend yield of 3.1% does not make the stock particularly compelling. We maintain our HOLD recommendation with our unchanged fair value of S$9.50.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand
arguments: We continue to value SIA on an SOTP basis, with the airline operations valued at 0.75x book value and SIA Engineering valued at S$2.55. We lower our suggested entry price to $8.70, which approximates a 10% total return to our target price.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Cargo Traffic Could Be Offset By Strong Underlying Pax Demand

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: Singapore Airlines - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: Improved passenger flown revenue.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: Weaker demand for cargo.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: Record PLF of 83.2% for SIA parent airline.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SIA, SGX:C6L)’s 1QFY20 net profit fell 20.7% y-o-y, or S$29m to S$111m, which was below ours and the street’s estimates. The decline was primarily due to a higher share of losses from associated companies which reported a loss of S$31m, with higher estimated losses from Virgin Australia, and higher finance charges (-S$26m).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: SIA’s 1QFY20 revenue grew 6.7% y-o-y, or S$258m to S$4.1b, on the back of higher flown revenue (+6.3% y-o-y, or S$226m). Passenger flown revenue improved 8.8% y-o-y on the back of higher traffic growth (+8.1% y-o-y) and capacity (+6.6% y-o-y), while cargo flown revenue dropped S$45m or 8.4% y-o-y.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: We expect the uncertainties over the US-China trade dispute and economic slowdown could continue to weigh on cargo demand.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: SIA's 1QFY20 expenditure increased by 6.9% y-o-y, or S$251m to S$3.9b, mainly from the expansion of its operations. Ex-fuel costs rose S$157m or 6.1% y-o-y, largely driven by higher staff cost (+13.7% y-o-y), in-line with the capacity increase. Net fuel-cost was up 8.7% y-o-y, or S$94m, due to higher volume uplifted on capacity expansion and a stronger US dollar.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: Despite of the higher expenditure, SIA’s 1QFY20 operating profit came in at S$200m, a 3.6% or S$7m increase compared to 1QFY19 due to higher revenue.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: SIA reported higher passenger traffic growth across all airlines as measured by revenue passenger-kilometres (+9.0% for SIA parent airline, +2.4% for SilkAir and 6.5% for Scoot). SIA parent airline’s operating profit grew strong at 28% y-o-y or $51 million to $232 million in 1QFY20.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: In terms of passenger load factor (PLF), SIA parent airline posted a record PLF of 83.2% (+1.2 percentage points), the highest on record for the first quarter.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: For SilkAir, measures have been taken to mitigate the grounding impact of the 737 Boeing Max 8 aircraft and it managed to contain the reduction in capacity to 1.6%. Despite the grounding impact, SilkAir’s PLF and unit revenue (RASK) rose 3.1 percentage points and 1.3% y-o-y respectively.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: Separately, to improve the operational resilience, Scoot proactively reduced aircraft utilisation and kept some spare aircrafts to make sure it adheres to time schedules in case of technical issues. As a result, Scoot’s capacity growth was restrained to 6.5% and PLF remained unchanged at 86.1% in 1QFY20.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: Looking ahead, passenger bookings in the forward months are tracking against the capacity growth, supported by strong premium cabin traffic to key markets. Fuel price volatility is expected to continue in the near term, but SIA could continue to benefit from its strong hedge position.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: Despite the headwinds, we see that SIA is on track in its transformation, with improvement in overall RASK (+1.3% y-o-y), PLF (+1.1 percentage points y-o-y) and passenger traffic (+8.1% y-o-y) in 1QFY20.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Improved Passenger Traffic Growth
arguments: We maintain BUY with unchanged fair value estimate of S$11.02.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SIA, SGX:C6L) highlighted that on a currency adjusted basis, pax yields rose 3% y-o-y, underpinned by strong premium loads and yields. The key uncertainty is when or if this will reverse.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: For now, SIA is positive on yields, which implies that at least for the next 3-4 months yields should be supported. Aside from a weak cargo environment, escalating staff costs and a deteriorating earnings outlook for Virgin Australia are key risks.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: Earnings would have been flat were it not for S$31m in losses recognised from Virgin Australia (VA).

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: Virgin Australia had guided that it will recognise S$160m in losses for 2H19 (June year-end). Singapore Airlines (SIA) subsequently recognised roughly S$31m in losses for the quarter, reversing 4QFY19’s profit estimate as well. Were it not for that, PBT and net profit would have been flat y-o-y.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: On a currency adjusted basis, SIA’s pax yield would have risen by 3% yoy,

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: underpinned by strong premium loads, higher proportion of premium seats and improved pricing on premium cabins. This offset the yield pressure on the back end.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: Weakness in the AUD, GBP, Euro and IDR had a negative impact on pax yields for 1QFY20.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: SIA noted strong demand for premium cabins on Asia-Southwest Pacific regions but intra-Asia, particularly North Asia, faced pressure on the backend cabins, due to excess capacity.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: Staff cost rose a whopping 14% yoy (+$90m), well ahead of the 6.6% yoy rise in pax capacity.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: Part of this was due to the completion of a collective agreement with pilots, while SIA also awarded performance bonuses pegged on improved pax load factor.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: Scoot’s S$37m operating loss was mainly due to a reduction in block time utilisation hours.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: Given negative publicity over the delays in the prior quarter, Scoot had reduced the utilisation in the current quarter by 2 hrs to 9hrs in comparison to 4QFY19. This, along with lower yields and weaker demand out of Singapore led to the steep losses in 1QFY20. Comparatively, Scoot reported a loss of S$6.0m in 4QFY19.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: SIA not optimistic on cargo recovery but impact to bottom line appears to be muted.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: SIA noted that there was excess capacity across the region and yields are likely to remain weak. Still, cargo revenue fell by just S$44.6m in 1QFY20 vs a S$258m rise in pax flown revenue. The net impact at the operating level, was a S$52m increase in operating profit for the parent airline operations.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: Key uncertainty is the extent to which pax demand could slow down amid the current weak environment. We have assumed a 1% y-o-y rise in pax yield but still expect core net profit to decline by 21.8% y-o-y.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: We have lowered our FY20 net profit assumption by 4.2%, after factoring in higher staff cost and losses from Virgin Australia.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: We continue to value SIA on an SOTP basis by valuing the airline operations at 0.75x P/B and SIA Engineering (SGX:S59) at our fair value of S$2.55.

title: Singapore Airlines Briefing Takeaways  - Pax Yields Still Holding Up, Underpinned By Robust Premium Demand
arguments: We however lower our recommended entry price to S$9.10.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: Singapore Airlines - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: At today’s analyst briefing, SINGAPORE AIRLINES (SIA, SGX:C6L) said that passenger demand for the mainline carrier remained robust, with premium cabin yields holding steady.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: The carrier is monitoring negative momentum in macroeconomic indicators, including airfreight weakness, that may portend a turn in the aviation cycle.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: Maintain HOLD, with an unchanged target price of S$10.04, still pegged to P/BV of 0.9x (1 s.d. below mean).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) hosted a briefing for analysts this morning, and this briefing note is best read in conjunction with our results report issued earlier today, where we downgraded our core EPS forecasts by 16-18% and reduced the target price to S$10.04. See Singapore Airlines - CGS-CIMB 2019-08-01: Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: We noted in our results report that SIA was not a compelling investment case at Wednesday’s closing price of S$9.67, but after the sell-off today, SIA is once again closing in on its trough P/BV valuation of 0.8x, or S$8.93, which is just 3% lower than the current SIA share price. Nevertheless, we are not upgrading our call to an Add, because the earnings momentum for SIA looks set to decelerate, given the ongoing cargo demand and yield weakness, and an expected delayed flow-through in the future to premium demand and yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: SIA told analysts that conditions were hunky-dory for the mainline passenger carrier to-date, with premium demand and yields holding up, although economy class yields were under a bit of competitive pressure. Looking three months forward, no weakness has been detected, contrary to Cathay Pacific’s warnings of substantial pressure on long-haul passenger yields in the coming months. However, SIA is worried about the weakening global economic momentum indicators, which had preceded a weakening of business travel demand and yields in the past.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: SIA is bearish on the outlook for its cargo business, as the US-China trade war has caused demand to fall while freighter capacity put in place during the cargo boom years of 2017-18 have remained in place, causing oversupply and continuing to put pressure on cargo yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: SilkAir’s grounding of its six 737 MAX 8 planes caused non-fuel operating costs to escalate, as it continues to depreciate the planes while generating no revenue from them. With multiple regulatory hurdles to clear, SilkAir was unsure when the planes could be reactivated, which means SilkAir’s financial performance might be lacklustre for a while yet.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: Meanwhile, Scoot continues to face issues with the reliability of the Rolls-Royce TRENT 1000 engines powering its 787-9 fleet, which had caused lengthy flight delays in the last few months of 2018 and a fall-off at its Singapore point-of-sale. As a result, Scoot has been forced to curtail its aircraft utilisation by 15% or two hours a day, and set aside more spare aircraft, which impacted its planned capacity expansion.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: Once the technical issues on the MAX 8 and TRENT 1000 engines are resolved, SilkAir and Scoot will be achieve their true long-term potential.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Okay For Now, But Darker Clouds On The Horizon
arguments: See attached 15-page PDF report for complete analysis and outlook of SIA mainline, SilkAir, Scoot, SIA Cargo.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: Singapore Airlines - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: SIA's 1QFY3/20 core net profit made up 13% of our/consensus previous forecasts, underperforming expectations due to SIA’s share of Virgin Australia’s losses.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: Maintain HOLD as we see cyclical headwinds from slowing global trade growth, potentially affecting both premium-cabin travel and cargo volumes.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: Our target price is still based on 0.9x CY19 P/BV (1 s.d. below mean), but lowered to S$10.04 on the back of reductions in our earnings forecasts .

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments:
SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SIA, SGX:C6L)'s 1QFY20 core net profit of S$108m was 20% lower y-o-y, due mainly to the swing in associate and JV contributions from share of profits in 1QFY19 to a share of losses in 1QFY20, which in turn, was caused by an unfavourable swing to losses at Virgin Australia, partially offset by an improvement in Vistara’s performance. Taking that aside, last quarter’s EBIT was flattish y-o-y, with an operating profit improvement at

SIA mainline’s passenger business and at
SIA Engineering (SGX:S59), largely offset by
lower cargo profits, and
losses at SilkAir and Scoot (vs. breakeven for the latter two airlines in the prior year).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: SIA mainline’s passenger business and at

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: SIA Engineering (SGX:S59), largely offset by

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: lower cargo profits, and

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: losses at SilkAir and Scoot (vs. breakeven for the latter two airlines in the prior year).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: SilkAir grounded its fleet of six 737 MAX 8 planes on 12 Mar 2019, and 1QFY20 reflected the first full quarter of that impact with an EBIT loss of S$16m, vs. breakeven last year. Costs related to the grounding and loss of revenue from the subsequent reduction of capacity contributed the majority of the loss. This was partly compensated by SilkAir’s third-consecutive quarter of y-o-y RASK increase as passenger demand and loads responded positively to lower yields. The efforts to improve RASK are important because SilkAir had over-expanded by growing ASK capacity 36% over the past four years, which led to a 15% RASK decline over that same period.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: During our recent marketing trip to Singapore, many investors asked if there was a case to accumulate SIA shares. At its recent low of S$9.06 on 4 Jun, SIA was certainly very attractive, trading at its trough valuation of 0.8x P/BV, but at the current share price of S$9.67, the upside is no longer so compelling, in our view. See SIA share price history.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: Cathay Pacific recently warned of “intense market competition” that “continued to exert pressure on yield” especially on long-haul flights. SIA also noted that trade disputes and softer airfreight demand has clouded the outlook for passenger demand over the longer term.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: Our HOLD call is premised on weakening global GDP growth and higher tariffs that are now beleaguering the US-China trade and have been negatively affecting SIA’s airfreight demand and yield since late-CY18. There is a historical lagged correlation between cargo demand and demand for premium-cabin and business-related travel, which pose a downside risk.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Share Price Constrained By Mixed Outlook
arguments: Upside risks include the potential for SilkAir to rethink its long-term capacity growth by renegotiating the 737 MAX 8 orders with Boeing.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: Singapore Airlines - A Modest Start To FY20

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES (SGX:C6L)'s 1Q20 EBIT improved 4% y-o-y to S$200m on 7%revenue growth to S$4.1bn.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: Higher finance charges and associate losses dragged net earnings to decline 20% y-o-y to S$111m.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: Expect earnings to be stronger sequentially ahead as transformation programme bears fruit.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: Maintain BUY, Target Price S$10.80.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES (SGX:C6L) reported 1QFY20 core operating profits that were in line with expectations but share of losses at Virgin Australia caused net earnings to be slightly below expectations.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: Revenue for the quarter grew by 6.7% y-o-y to S$4.1bn, led by firm passenger carriage growth of 8% at flagship SIA. This offset lower revenues at SIA Cargo and Silkair, which was impacted by the grounding of its six B737-MAX aircraft.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: Operating expenditure grew slightly faster than revenue at 6.9%, with hedging gains partially offsetting higher fuel costs. As a result, operating earnings improved 3.6% y-o-y to S$200m.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: EBIT contributions from the key segments were mixed, with a strong performance from the flagship SIA segment (+28% y-o-y to S$232m) offsetting weaker showings at Silkair (losses of S$16m vs. breakeven a year ago) and Scoot (S$37m loss vs. S$1m profit). Below the EBIT line, higher finance charges and losses from associates of S$30m (versus a gain of S$1.3m a year ago), due to higher estimated losses from Virgin Australia, caused net earnings to decline by 20% y-o-y to S$111m.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: Despite the modest start to Singapore Airlines’s financial year, there are encouraging signs that its flagship segment, which contributes the bulk of the group’s earnings, is doing well amidst challenges for its other segments. The firm revenue growth at the flagship SIA segment is a positive sign that its transformation continues to bear fruit.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: Furthermore, the first quarter is seasonally the weakest quarter and we expect earnings ahead to show sequential improvement.

title: Singapore Airlines  - A Modest Start To FY20
arguments: Our target price is based on 0.95x FY20F P/BV, which is at Singapore Airlines’s 5-year average price-to-book valuation.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: Singapore Airlines - 1QFY20: Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SIA, SGX:C6L)’s 1QFY20 net profit came in within our expectation but non-operating profit suffered steep losses arising from provisions on associate Virgin Australia.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: The parent airline’s better-than-expected operating profit was mainly due to a lower-than-expected decline in cargo yield (-4.2% y-o-y).

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: SIA is upbeat on near-term prospects, citing strong passenger forward bookings against capacity growth.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: Maintain HOLD. Target price: S$9.50. Entry price: S$9.20.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: Earnings below expectation as SIA recognises loses on 20%-owned Virgin Australia. Operating profit was in line with our estimate of S$205m but non-operating earnings surprised on the downside as SIA estimated a significant loss provision on associate Virgin Australia. 1QFY20’s earnings amounted to 15.9% and 13.2% of our and the street’s full-year estimates. SIA’s book value stood at S$10.65 per share, down 5.1% from Mar 19, due mainly to the adoption of lease accounting.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: Parent airline operations were stronger than expected as extent of decline in cargo yield was lower than expectation. (-4.2% vs -5.8% estimate). Pax yield improved and was in line with estimates, rising by 1%. Earnings would have been even higher for the parent airline if not for an additional S$15.4m in D&A that was recognised, due to changes in the residual value estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: Operating cash flow after working capital rose by 27.6% yoy to S$842m, registering a decent margin of 20.5%.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: Silk Air S$16m loss, largely due to 1.6% decline in capacity, which was in turn due to the grounding of B737 Max aircraft, while weak yields (-2.9% y-o-y) led to a S$10m revenue shortfall.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: Scoot reported a S$36m loss as other operating revenue (presumably leases to Nok Scoot) fell by S$10m and due to a 1.8% y-o-y decline in pax yield, coupled with a 3.9% y-o-y rise in unit cost.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: SIA has hedged 70% of fuel requirements for FY19/20 jet fuel requirements at US$76/bbl and another 5% on Brent at US$52/bbl. Longer dated hedges till FY24/25 amount to 46% of SIA’s fuel requirements, ranging from US$58-63/bbl on Brent.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: Decent results, notwithstanding losses at Virgin Australia; SIA is also upbeat on near term prospects. The carrier noted that “passenger bookings in the forward months are tracking closely against capacity growth, supported by premium cabin traffic to key markets”.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: Still, SIA noted that a weakening air freight environment could eventually “cloud the outlook for passenger demand”. We share SIA’s concerns though we believe that the risk to passenger traffic could be sooner, given Singapore’s own weakening economic environment.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: No change to our forecasts.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: We will provide further information, post an analyst briefing. For now, maintain HOLD and target price of S$9.50.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 1QFY20 Decent Results, But Risks To Passenger Demand Could Come Sooner Than Expected
arguments: Unclear at this stage.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Strong Pax Traffic But Cargo Traffic Declines For 9 Straight Months
