title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Pax traffic remained robust, with SIA’s pax traffic rising 6.6% y-o-y for Mar 19 and 8.8% y-o-y for 4QFY19. However, cargo traffic declined y-o-y for seven straight months.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Uncertainty regarding the grounded aircraft is likely to limit upside over the next three months. SIA also faces downward risk to profits due to the rise in jet fuel costs.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Maintain HOLD and target price of S$10.10.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Suggested entry level is at S$9.00.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: 8.8% y-o-y rise in pax traffic in 4QFY19 for parent airline.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Singapore Airlines Ltd (SIA, SGX:C6L)’ pax carriage rose 7.8% y-o-y in 4QFY19, indicating strong underlying demand.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Pax load factor declined 1.2 ppt y-o-y in Mar 19 but improved marginally by 0.5 ppt y-o-y in 4QFY19. Except for West Asia and Africa, there was a broad-based decline in pax load factors for the parent airline, with flights to and from the Americas showing the biggest y-o-y weakness (-3.4ppt) in Mar 19. SIA indicated that the 1.9% decline in SilkAir’s capacity was due to B737 Max’s temporary withdrawal.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Cargo traffic declined y-o-y for seven straight months, while load factor fell y-o-y for five consecutive months.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Cargo load factors declined 2.2ppt y-o-y in Mar 19.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: All routes reported lower cargo load factors in Mar 19, with South West Pacific registering the largest decrease of 4.1ppt y-o-y mainly due to weakening global PMI and slowing intra-Asia trade.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Uncertainty regarding the grounded aircraft is likely to limit upside over the next three months.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Six of SilkAir’s B737 Max aircraft have been grounded since mid-March, accounting for 20% of its current seat capacity. SIA has also grounded two B787-10 jets due to wear and tear on engine blades.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: We now believe that B737 Max aircraft is likely to remain grounded beyond our initial July estimate. On 5 April, Boeing announced it will be reducing the production of B737 Max aircraft from 52 to 42 aircrafts monthly. This implies that the airline does not expect a quick solution and also could be expecting further order cancellations.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: While we believe SIA will be compensated for loss of revenue, we still believe there is downside risk to revenue, profits and cash flow. The capacity constraint will be exasperated by the grounding of two of SIA’s nine B787-10 aircraft. Future delivery of 38 outstanding orders could also be affected due to engine shortage.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Ytd rise in jet fuel costs to US$82.60/bbl also poses risk to profitability.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Still, this is in line with our estimated average fuel price of US$82/bbl for FY20. SIA has hedged 65% of jet fuel requirement for FY20 at US$74/bbl. Every US$5 rise in average jet fuel price will result in a S$297m change in PBT for FY20.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: We have made marginal changes to our net profit assumptions for FY19 (+1.5%) and FY20 (+2.5%) due to slightly higher-than-expected full-year operating statistics.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: We continue to value SIA on an SOTP basis, with the airline operations valued at 0.75x book value. Our fair value remains at S$10.10.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: Suggested entry price remains at $9.00.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Demand For Pax Traffic Remains Strong But Uncertainty About B737 Max’s Grounding Remains The Biggest Concern
arguments: None.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But We Lower Silkair’s FY20 Traffic Growth On The Back Of B737 Max’s Grounding

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Underlying demand for pax traffic remained buoyant in Feb 19, with SIA’s and SilkAir’s pax traffic rising 9.1% y-o-y and 4.6% y-o-y respectively. Cargo traffic however registered the biggest decline in FY19, with load factors falling to GFC levels.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Even so, the grounding of B737 Max remains the biggest concern, not just on foregone revenue but also of future demand.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: We cut our FY20 net profit forecast by S$38m, factoring in an 8% y-o-y decline in traffic for SilkAir.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Maintain HOLD. Target price: $10.10. Entry price: $9.00.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: 9.1% y-o-y rise in pax traffic in Feb 19 for parent airline.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Taking into account combined traffic for Jan-Feb 19 to remove any anomalies arising from an earlier Chinese New Year, pax traffic rose 10% y-o-y. indicating strong underlying demand. SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L) indicated that it attempted to maintain RASK (pax revenue-to-capacity) despite the strong competition.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Scoot’s traffic growth has moderated for four consecutive months, leading to a - 1.5ppt decline in load factor. We note that ytd 4QFY19’s pax load factor of 84.8ppt was lower than 3QFY19’s breakeven levels, suggesting likely losses for the low-cost carrier.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Pax load factor improved marginally by 0.4ppt in Feb and by 1.5ppt in 2M19.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: West Asia and Africa registered the highest y-o-y increase (+ 4.1ppt) followed by Europe (+1.7ppt) and South West Pacific (+0.5ppt). However, pax load factors declined for both East Asia (-0.4ppt) and Americas (-2.4ppt).

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Staggering 15.1% y-o-y decline in cargo traffic for Feb 19 reflects weakening intra-Asia trade volume.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: February’s decline was also the highest for FY19 and marked six straight months of decline. All routes reported lower load factors, with East Asia registering the largest decrease of 8.7%.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Load factors were similarly weak, declining 6.8ppt and registering the lowest level since Jan 09.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Concerns over B737 Max deliveries and grounding will overshadow strong pax data.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: SilkAir’s six B737 Max aircraft have been grounded and the carrier has outstanding orders for 31 such aircraft. The grounded aircraft make up about 20% of SilkAir’s current seat capacity.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: While the parent airline is likely to add flights to offset the lost capacity from the grounded aircraft, we still estimate a S$110m-130m in revenue shortfall as well as about S$30m in fixed costs until this year-end.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: However, Boeing is reportedly offering a software solution by April and if all goes well, the B737 Max aircraft might be cleared to operate by July. We also believe that Singapore Airlines is likely to receive compensation for the grounded aircraft.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: We raise FY19 net profit estimate by 1% to factor in better-than-expected pax traffic, offset by weaker cargo traffic.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: However, we lower our FY20 net profit assumption by 6%, or S$38m, factoring in a conservative 8% decline in traffic for SilkAir.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: We do not envisage any positive catalyst for at least one more quarter There is also the risk that load factors on the B737 Max would be low for some time, even if the aircraft is cleared to fly.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: We continue to value Singapore Airlines on an SOTP basis. Our fair value is lowered from S$10.20 to S$10.10 due to FY20’s earnings revision.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: Suggested entry price remains at $9.00.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Pax Traffic Remains Robust In Feb 19 But ...
arguments: None.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: Singapore Airlines - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: Although SilkAir’s fleet of six Boeing 737 MAX 8 make up 16% of its seat capacity, the net impact of their grounding is nowhere that significant.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: By raising aircraft utilisation and with help from SIA mainline, we calculate the net loss of capacity at only 1.5% of SilkAir’s systemwide seat capacity.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: Maintain HOLD, with an unchanged target price of S$10.25, based on 0.9x CY19F P/BV (1 s.d. below mean since 2001).

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: An Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 737 MAX 8 flight crashed on 10 Mar and similarities with a Lion Air crash of the same model five months previously have led aviation regulators across the world to ground the MAX 8/9 planes.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: On 12 Mar, SilkAir grounded its 6 x Boeing MAX 8 planes. Boeing plans to install a software update in Apr, which then needs to be tested. This means that the grounding of the model will not be lifted until at least May, if not later.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: See attached PDF report for the list of existing Boeing 737 MAX operators.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: Apart from the 6 x MAX 8 planes, SilkAir also has 2 x A319s, 8 x A320s and 17 x 737- 800 ‘new-generation’ planes. There are no technical issues for the 737-800 planes.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: The MAX 8 planes make up 18% of SilkAir’s current fleet but the impact on SilkAir is much smaller than that. We estimate that the MAX 8 flights make up 16% of SilkAir’s seat capacity and 26% of its Available Seat Kilometre (ASK) capacity.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: However, with the announced schedule changes for 16-30 Mar, the impact of the MAX 8 grounding will amount to only 1.5% of SilkAir’s systemwide seat capacity as SilkAir has increased the utilisation of its A320 and 737-800 planes and SIA mainline has mounted supplementary widebody flights. Only SIA/SilkAir’s seat capacity to KL, Hyderabad and Wuhan will see mid-teens percentage declines while Phuket will see a mid-single-digit percentage drop.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: The MAX 8 planes are envisioned as the cornerstone of its future fleet because SilkAir has orders for a further 31 x MAX planes. Also, SilkAir had planned to retire the existing Airbus fleet and 3 x 737-800 planes and to transfer 14 x 737-800 aircraft and several regional routes to Scoot (originally to be effected between Apr 2019F and 3QCY20F). Once all this is completed, SilkAir will operate only one aircraft type, i.e. the MAX planes, in up to three possible variants (MAX 8/9/10).

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: Furthermore, SilkAir plans to retrofit its MAX planes with lie-flat business class seats and seatback In-Flight Entertainment (IFE) in order to offer a comparable product with SIA mainline, upon which SilkAir will be formally merged with its parent company into one SIA brand. All these plans, including the delivery of MAX 8 orders from Boeing, retirement/transfer of other models and seat retrofit, will now likely be delayed due to the MAX grounding.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: At the same time, it may be possible for SilkAir to claim compensation from Boeing for the MAX groundings, either in the form of a direct cash transfer or discounts on future aircraft deliveries. We think it is too early to assess the long-term impact on SilkAir and the wider SIA group.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments:
SilkAir currently has a fleet of 33 planes, comprising:

2 x A319-100 planes (128 seats),
8 x A320-200 planes (150 seats),
17 x B737-800NG planes (“NG” stands for new-generation, 162 seats), and
6 x B737 MAX 8 planes (156 seats).

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 2 x A319-100 planes (128 seats),

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 8 x A320-200 planes (150 seats),

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 17 x B737-800NG planes (“NG” stands for new-generation, 162 seats), and

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 6 x B737 MAX 8 planes (156 seats).

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: The 737 MAX 8 planes are SilkAir’s newest planes and make up 18% of SilkAir’s fleet by number.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: SilkAir has a further 31 orders for the type to be delivered over the next five years, i.e. seven deliveries in 2019F, and six deliveries each in 2020-2023F.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments:
Prior to the grounding of SilkAir’s six Boeing 737 MAX 8 planes on the morning of 12 March 2019, SilkAir operated 64 flights/week using 737 MAX 8 planes to 12 destinations, including:

16 flights/week to India (Bangalore and Hyderabad)
11 flights/week to China (Chongqing and Wuhan)
11 flights/week to Thailand (Phuket)
9 flights/week to Australia (Cairns and Darwin)
6 flights/week to Nepal (Kathmandu)
4 flights/week to Malaysia (Kuala Lumpur and Penang)
4 flights/week to Cambodia (Phnom Penh)
3 flights/week to Japan (Hiroshima)

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 16 flights/week to India (Bangalore and Hyderabad)

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 11 flights/week to China (Chongqing and Wuhan)

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 11 flights/week to Thailand (Phuket)

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 9 flights/week to Australia (Cairns and Darwin)

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 6 flights/week to Nepal (Kathmandu)

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 4 flights/week to Malaysia (Kuala Lumpur and Penang)

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 4 flights/week to Cambodia (Phnom Penh)

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: 3 flights/week to Japan (Hiroshima)

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: SilkAir’s flights on the 737 MAX 8s make up 16% of SilkAir’s total flight frequencies, 16.1% of its seat capacity and 25.8% of its Available Seat Kilometre (ASK) capacity. Against the SIA group as a whole, which also includes SIA mainline and Scoot, the significance of SilkAir’s 737 MAX 8 flights are diminished to just 3.5% of the sum total of SIA group’s flight frequencies, 2.3% of group seat capacity and 1.7% of group ASK capacity.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: The 737 MAX 8 operations have the lowest significance in Malaysia, where they account for only 2-4% of overall group flight frequencies to Kuala Lumpur and Penang. This is because SilkAir also flies to those destinations using other aircraft types, SIA mainline serves KL separately and Scoot also services those two destinations using the low-cost model.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: On routes to Bangalore, Phnom Penh and Phuket, SilkAir’s 737 MAX 8 flights make up some 21-24% of group flight frequencies. SilkAir services Phnom Penh and Phuket extensively using other aircraft types while Bangalore is serviced by both SIA mainline and Scoot; Phuket is also serviced by Scoot.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: On Hyderabad and Wuhan, the 737 MAX 8 presence is much higher, at 57-65% of group flight frequencies. Wuhan is serviced exclusively by SilkAir but SilkAir also deploys other aircraft types to the destination. SilkAir services Hyderabad using only 737 MAX 8s but Scoot has a separate service to the city.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: Finally, the 737 MAX 8s are used by SilkAir to service five cities on an exclusive basis, i.e. Cairns and Darwin in Australia, Chongqing, Hiroshima and Kathmandu. Erstwhile, no other carrier in the SIA group services these cities, and SilkAir does not use other aircraft types to these cities either.

title: Singapore Airlines  - B737 MAX Grounding Not Significant To SIA
arguments: See attached PDF report for details on SilkAir's schedule changes for 16- 30 March due to the grounding of the Boeing 737 MAX 8 planes.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: As usual, SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L, SIA)'s management provided a cautious outlook during the 3QFY19 analyst briefing. However, the undertone is they have passed the worst and there are just a few tweaks needed.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: The parent airline and cargo business is operating well, whereas the regional short haul suffers from overcapacity and a sudden fall-off of Chinese tourists.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: We are confident Singapore Airlines will meet our FY19E. Re-iterate BUY and Target Price of SGD11.20 (0.94x FY19F P/BV — its 10-year mean).

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: The industry is very volatile at the moment due to uncertainty over US-China trade war. This has caused a sudden shift in consumer behaviour, especially business travel and Chinese tourists. Overcapacity looms on certain routes due to this as airlines have yet to adjust their capacities.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: In Singapore Airlines’s case, routes within the ASEAN region, as well as to China and India are impacted. Otherwise, Singapore Airlines has achieved its first growth in passenger yields since 2016, which indicates the bottom has been reached.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Singapore Airlines’s fuel hedge provided net savings of SGD102m in 3QFY19. For 9MFY19, it had net savings of SGD386m.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Singapore Airlines has hedged 80% of its 4QFY19 fuel requirements at USD74/bbl, which is slightly lower than the current market price. This will enable Singapore Airlines to price its inventories more effectively and precisely as compared to its competitors that are mostly lightly hedged or entirely on the spot market.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: We like Singapore Airlines for its modest capacity growth strategy, which should enable it to manage yields relatively better than its competitors. Its fuel hedge reduces operating risk significantly and greatly safeguards positive margins going forward.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Furthermore, its sub 5% dividend yield is attractive compared to other carriers and the STI.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Passenger demand matches supply

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: The Group was able to fill up its seats fairly well in 3QFY19, as exhibited by the record load factor of 82.8%. The keyword is active capacity management and selling promotional seats well ahead of time. Furthermore, Singapore Airlines is very clinical in adding capacity and quick to make adjustments based on passenger demand.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Management indicated that the near-term outlook is pretty encouraging and expects a high level of passenger load factor. The areas that are under pressure are the short-haul and budget segment. These business segments are facing overcapacity on certain routes and this is putting pressure on yields.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Cargo still going strong, but dark clouds ahead

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: The cargo business is performing well. The Group managed to achieve high-single-digit yield growth, albeit at flat volumes. The US-China trade war spat has created a new level of uncertainty and many cargo shippers have abandoned long-term schedules for one-time consignments. The industry still has pricing power for now as most of the tariffs imposed are not on goods shipped via air and therefore largely unaffected.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: However, should a new tariff encroach into high-value and time-sensitive cargos, this can quickly diminish air cargo carriers’ pricing power. The situation is very volatile and nobody could put their finger on what would be the next rendition between the US-China trade war episodes.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Making good progress on yields

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: The graphs below show the yield movement of the passenger and cargo businesses since FY12. We are encouraged by the performance in 3QFY19, as Singapore Airlines was able to achieve respectable yield growth despite a challenging operating environment. We believe the momentum will continue into FY20 and this should help to boost profits and cash flows.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Risk adverse approach on fuel

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Singapore Airlines has hedged 80% of its 4QFY19 fuel requirements at USD74/bbl, which is slightly lower than the current market price of USD78. For FY20, it has hedged 69% of its fuel requirements at levels below current market prices. Management highlights that it will actively sought more fuel-hedging exposure should the market present itself with opportunities.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3QFY19 Below Due To Tax, But Things Are Under Control
arguments: Singapore Airlines has the second highest fuel-hedge coverage ratio among the Asia Pacific carriers. This is proving to be a great advantage as it has locked in the fuel price at attractive levels. This also enables Singapore Airlines to sell its tickets longer into the future as the risk profile has been significantly reduced.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP) - 3QFY19: Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: While SIA's 3QFY19 earnings were better than expected, we still do not see that as a catalyst for upward revision.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: While pax yields or RASK could be maintained into the next two quarters, there is a strong likelihood that demand could falter as the global economy slows down. We already see signs of that for the cargo business.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: We maintain our HOLD rating, with an unchanged target price.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: Suggested entry level, S$9.50.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: Admirable quarter, given headwinds and 6.9% pax capacity growth at group level.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L, SIA)’s 3QFY19 net profit came in 25% and 27% above our and street estimates respectively. The earnings beat was due to stronger-than-expected pax yields, which turned out to be flat y-o-y vs our expectation of a 1% y-o-y decline and lower than expected non-fuel cost.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: Group revenue grew 6.4%, underpinned by a 7.7% rise in pax flown revenue. Despite that, operating profit was weak, due to a 27% y-o-y rise in into-plane fuel cost.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: Operating cash flow before working capital changes was nonetheless higher by 2.6%.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: Pax yields remain firm on long haul, but faces pressure on short haul regional routes.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: SIA singled out the US routes as having the strong load factors and favourable yields on the front end, but noted weaker pricing on the back end for the same sector. SIA also noted strong demand and yields on the direct business and premium economy only flights to Los Angeles and New York.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: In addition, SIA noted that for the parent airline, yields would have risen by 2% y-o-y, were it not for a stronger Singapore dollar.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: JV & associate income (-66.6%) dragged down by Vistara and Nok Scoot in 3QFY19.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: Virgin Australia, in which SIA has a 20% share, saw profits surging 16-fold to A$73.8m.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: SIA also invested S$184m in Vistara in 3QFY19 to fund the latter’s capex. Total investment in the airline amounted to S$370m.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: SIA sees a general slowdown in cargo demand since Dec 18.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: This is consistent with an observation from WorldACD which highlighted a “double whammy” of negative volume and yields for December. SIA pointed out that cargo yields dipped 4.2% in December. We believe yields will fall further in 1Q19, drawing guidance from industry authority, Drewry which reported that rates dropped 3.5% m-o-m in January.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: SIA hedged 80% of jet fuel requirements for 4QFY19 at US$74/bbl vs 3QFY19’s 58% at US$71/bbl. For FY20, SIA has hedged 54% of jet fuel at US$76 and another 15% at US$55/bbl

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: A key positive is the fact that long haul yields are holding up.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: However, we are not sure to what extent the yields are a reflection of a period when consumer confidence was more buoyant. Yields typically fall as the economic cycle reverses and general cargo yields are a leading indicator of softer demand.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: Still, we are open to the possibility that SIA’s firmer yields are due to improved product offerings and could remain firm for the next six months.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: Cash flow concerns have not abated.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: We had previously highlighted that SIA could require additional funding.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: We raised our FY19 net profit forecast by 3% to reflect marginally better pax yields in 3QFY19.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: We maintain our target price of S$10.20, which is SOTP-based, factoring our fair value for SIA Engineering and 0.75x FY20F's book value for the remaining business.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA SP)  - 3QFY19 Earnings Beat, But Does Not Warrant A Re-rating
arguments: Better-than-expected cargo traffic.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: Singapore Airlines - Outlook For Fy20f Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: SIA’s 9MFY3/19 core net profit made up 92% of our full-year expectations, which is in line as a typical 4Q is seasonally weak.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: Maintain HOLD due to the tough competition, with an unchanged target price of S$10.25, based on 0.9x CY19F P/BV (1 s.d. below mean since 2001).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: The outlook for FY20F is better, due to the correction in jet fuel prices since Oct 2018, and because the US$ is no longer likely to appreciate significantly.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L)’s 3QFY19 core net profit of S$284m was 25% lower y-o-y on the back of higher average jet fuel prices, and the depreciation of revenue currencies such as the A$, € and £, while the appreciation of the US$ pushed up operating costs.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: Beyond the headline numbers, however, are some interesting dynamics. SIA mainline’s operating profits were rather flat y-o-y; while cost per available seat km (CASK) growth exceeded revenue per available seat km (RASK) expansion due to fuel cost increases and possible start-up losses of the non-stop A350-900ULR flights to the US that began in Oct and Nov 2018, SIA mainline may have seen growth in some non-ticket incomes.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: SIA group switched to a new revenue management system in CY17 and over the past five quarters had managed to increase SIA mainline’s RASK y-o-y by stimulating a large rise in demand and passenger load factor (PLF) by lowering yields, although CASK growth stole its thunder.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: SilkAir and Scoot’s operating profits fell significantly y-o-y in 3QFY19, but again, there are interesting nuances.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: SilkAir, which had an over-ambitious expansion plan, saw its RASK fall y-o-y over 12 quarters to 2QFY19, but managed to engineer 1.2% growth in RASK in 3QFY19 when its capacity expansion stopped. Unfortunately, this was not sufficient to cover a 4.9% rise in CASK.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: Scoot’s PLF fell 3.6% pts y-o-y in 3QFY19, the first in seven quarters. This may be partly due to the negative demand reaction from the hike in Changi airport tax from 1 Jul 2018, causing its RASK to drop 5.8% y-o-y vs. 8.3% rise in its CASK.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: The momentum for cargo demand and yield improvements have weakened as we progressed to Dec 2018, hence in 3QFY19, SIA’s cargo business failed to deliver growth to its revenue per unit of available freight tonne km (AFTK) capacity for the first time in the eight quarters. Its cargo’s unit profitability shrank y-o-y for the first time in 10 quarters.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: Refer to the PDF report attached for comparison of respective operating metrics.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: Lower oil prices should benefit FY20F earnings, based on an average all-in jet fuel price assumption of US$78.5/bbl for FY19F, and US$76.5/bbl for FY20F (inclusive of hedging gains). This reflects average spot jet fuel price assumptions of US$82/bbl and US$75/bbl, respectively. However, the increasingly-apparent cyclical weakness in cargo demand may offset some of the gains from cheaper fuel prices.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: We have not reflected potential earnings enhancements from the transfer of 14 x 737-800 narrowbody aircraft and regional routes from SilkAir to Scoot (to be effected between Apr 2019F and Jun 2020F).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: Upside risks to our call:

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: Lower-than-expected oil prices, depreciation of the US$ as a result of a potential pause in the US Federal Funds Rate increases, and improved group profits once the 737-800 planes are transferred from SilkAir to Scoot.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: Downside risks:

title: Singapore Airlines  - Outlook For FY20F Has Improved On Cheaper Fuel
arguments: Larger-than-expected start-up losses from its ultra long range (ULR) services as a result of low, promotional yields or lower-than-expected load factors.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: SIA’s 3Q19 net profit of S$284m (-27% y-o-y, +400% q-o-q) in line with expectations.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: Flagship passenger segment posted a marginal improvement in EBIT despite higher fuel costs on higher passenger load factor and tight non-fuel cost control.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: Earnings to continue to recover on lower fuel costs and as the ongoing transformation programme pays off.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: Maintain BUY, Target Price S$11.00.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: SIA reported 3Q19 net profit of S$284m, which declined 27% y-o-y but showed a fourfold improvement from 2Q19

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L, SIA) reported 3Q19 net profit of S$284m, which declined 27% y-o-y but showed a fourfold improvement from 2Q19, and was in line with our expectations.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: Revenue grew 6.5% y-o-y to S$4.34bn mainly on growth in passenger demand with passenger yields being flat. Operating costs outpaced revenue growth at 9.1% y-o-y mainly due to a 22.2% increase in fuel costs as a result of higher average jet fuel price during the quarter. Hence, operating profit fell 14.6% y-o-y to S$387.6m.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: On a segmental basis, the flagship SIA passenger business posted a marginal growth in EBIT contribution to S$369m, offset by substantially lower contributions from Silkair (S$7m in 3Q19 vs S$19m in 3Q18) and Scoot (S$1m in 3Q19 and S$43m in 3Q18). SIA ENGINEERING CO LTD (SGX:S59)’s EBIT contribution fell by 16% y-o-y to S$16m.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: While SIA’s 3Q earnings were lower compared to last year’s figures, it improved significantly from the previous two quarters, thanks to higher load factors and stringent non-fuel cost control. SIA’s flagship passenger segment performed well by posting an improvement in passenger load factor of 1.8ppts to 83.4% while keeping passenger yield stable, enabling a decent growth in revenues for the segment. This helped to partially offset the weaker performances of Scoot and Silkair, both of which saw weaker yields during the quarter.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: Looking ahead, we expect SIA’s 4Q19 earnings to post a y-o-y improvement on lower fuel costs as spot jet fuel prices averaged US$80/bbl while the quarter-to-date average price of spot jet fuel is US$73/bbl and the current price is US$78/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: Coupled with strong momentum from SIA’s transformation programme to spur revenue growth, i.e. focusing on Revenue per Available Seat KM (ASK) through optimising the balance between yield and load factors, this should lead to better earnings for the carrier.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: We reiterate our BUY call on SIA, as we believe that lower fuel costs will lead to better earnings over the next two years. At the same time, the ongoing transformation programme could also lead to a sustained improvement in its operations and profits.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 3Q19 Results In Line; Maintain BUY
arguments: Our Target Price is maintained at S$11, which is based on 0.9x FY20F P/BV against a projected ROE of 6.5% for FY20.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - More People Are Flying

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: Higher passenger load factor.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: Better RASK.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: Cargo slowing.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L, SIA) reported a 6.5% y-o-y rise in revenue to S$4.34b but saw a 27.1% fall in net profit to S$284.1m in 3QFY19, bringing 9MFY19 net profit to S$480.1m, which was better than our expectations.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: A robust improvement in revenue (+S$265m) in 3Q largely offset higher fuel and non-fuel expenditure. The former was driven by growth in passenger demand (+S$245m or 7.7%), while cargo flown revenue was steady against last year (+S$3m or 0.5%), as stronger yields offset lower loads carried.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: Passenger traffic for the group rose 8.0% in 3Q, outpacing capacity growth, resulting in a 0.9ppt improvement in passenger load factor to 83.0%. Group RASK (revenue per available seat-km) increased 1.3% as transformation programme momentum continued.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: For cargo, however, things are starting to slow especially in Dec with a lower yield, mainly due to US-China trade tensions and reduction in demand from Europe.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: Fuel costs, the main contributor to cost at 32.8% in 3QFY19, rose 21.6% y-o-y with higher fuel prices and volume consumed from the expansion in operations. For 4QFY19, SIA has hedged 80% of its fuel needs in MOPS at a weighted average price of US$74.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: Longer-dated Brent hedges with maturities extending to FY23/24 cover up to 45% of SIA’s projected annual fuel consumption, at average prices ranging from US$55-63/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: Looking ahead, overall passenger bookings in the forward months are tracking capacity growth, but uncertainties surrounding US-China tariffs and their consequent effects on global trade flows, as well as Brexit, are clouding the overall demand outlook for both passenger and cargo.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: Meanwhile, from SIA’s perspective, demand for long-haul flight has been strong, and it is generally happy about performance relating to its US flights. Scoot, however, faces relatively lower load factors in certain routes such as those relating to China and those to North Asia via Bangkok.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - More People Are Flying
arguments: We tweak our estimates and our fair value estimate rises slightly from S$10.71 to S$11.02.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: Aviation – Singapore - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: We expect SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L) to report S$227m in net profit for 3QFY19, a 21% y-o-y decline on pre- SFRS 1-based numbers, and expect Singapore Airlines to be more cautious in its forward guidance.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: For SINGAPORE TECH ENGINEERING LTD (SGX:S63), we expect 4Q18 earnings to be hit by an impairment loss from the divestment of VT Leeboy India.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: For SATS LTD. (SGX:S58), we expect flat headline net profit but mid-to single-digit growth in underlying 3QFY19 net profit.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: SIA ENGINEERING CO LTD (SGX:S59) could be a wild card, with potential upside surprise from its engine JV.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: Top picks are SATS and ST Engineering.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: SIA and ST Engineering could surprise to the downside in the upcoming results, but we remain positive on ST Engineering.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: We expect SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L) to report S$211m in net profit for 3QFY19, a 21% y-o-y decline on pre-SFRS1 adjustment on 3QFY18 net profit.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: For SINGAPORE TECH ENGINEERING LTD (SGX:S63, ST Engineering), our full-year estimate is also lower than the street’s and, implicitly, we expect 4Q18 net profit of S$149m vs street expectations of S$169m. The variation is mainly due to our expectation that ST Engineering could report a S$22m disposal loss from the sale of Leeboy India (LBI). We believe that much of consensus estimates have not factored that in. Excluding that, our numbers are in line with street expectations. We also expect ST Engineering’s top-line growth to show a marked improvement due to guidance on higher orderbook recognition in 4Q18.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: SIA: Likely to post uninspiring results on the back of higher fuel costs and lower pax yields.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: Our estimated 21% y-o-y contraction in 3QFY19 net profit is based on pre-SFRS 1 adjustment for 3QFY18. Singapore Airlines is likely to revise upwards its 3QFY18 net profit by about S$100m to factor in lower D&A and hence the y-o-y decline in 3QFY19 earnings could be significantly higher.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: Key factors that are expected to contribute to lower earnings are a 16% y-o-y rise in jet fuel costs, lower fuel hedging gains as well as likely weak earnings from SilkAir and Scoot.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: We also expect the parent airline’s pax yield to decline 0.8% y-o-y in 3QFY18 but RASK to rise by 1.4% y-o-y. A 1% y-o-y change in pax yield from our base assumption is expected to lead to a 9.8% y-o-y change in net profit.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: SATS: 3QFY19 net profit likely to be flat yoy.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: Gateway services revenue growth and profitability were key drivers to SATS LTD. (SGX:S58)'s operating profit in 2QFY19. However, revenue growth for the segment could be affected by a decline in cargo handled, as Changi Airport’s air cargo volume in tonnage fell 0.9% y-o-y during the quarter.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: Still, after factoring in stronger contribution from TFK, higher food solutions revenue from China and the cruise business along with q-o-q improvement in associate earnings, we expect headline net profit to be flat y-o-y but underlying net profit to rise by mid-single-digits (3QFY18 included earn-out gains of S$4.5m).

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: SIA Engineering: Operating earnings likely to remain weak but net profit could show yoy growth underpinned by engine associates and JVs.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: We expect net profit of SIA ENGINEERING CO LTD (SGX:S59) for 2HFY19 to rise 5.7% y-o-y. If the pace of revenue decline slows substantially and margins remain stable, these could be catalysts for re-rating, especially if improving line maintenance revenue is a key contributor.

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: Stay invested in ST Engineering; key datapoints to watch out for are:

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: Remain neutral on Singapore Airlines; key datapoints to watch out for are:

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: We remain buyers on SATS; key datapoints to watch out for are:

title: Aviation – Singapore  - SIA & STE Could Surprise On The Downside; The Latter Due To One-Off Impairment Charges
arguments: We are also encouraged by SATS’ recent investments to build a new central kitchen in Tianjin, and ground handling and catering centres at Daxing in Beijing. We also expect SATS to raise its final dividend payout to S$0.13/share from S$0.12.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Upgrade SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L) to BUY from HOLD and raise Target Price 14% to SGD11.20 as we raise P/B multiple to the historical avg. from 1SD below due to lower risks to growth. Our revised Target Price is based on 10-year P/BV mean of 0.94x vs. 0.82 previously.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: We estimate 3QFY19 (out Feb-19) core net profit of SGD316m (+14% y-o-y, +80% q-o-q). 3QFY19’s overall load factor eased by 0.3ppt y-o-y and q-o-q to 76.1% and we expect yields to continue its downtrend (-1.1% y-o-y), but lower fuel price (-3% q-o-q) has more than offset this.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: We raise SIA's FY19-21E earnings by 33%, 37% and 17% respectively to factor in lower fuel price, better yield outlook, its latest traffic-growth plans and USD/SGD estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Overall traffic (passenger + cargo) in 3QFY19 grew 3.9% y-o-y. Load factor receded by 0.3ppt y-o-y to 76.1%, which is still considered high by historical comparison.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: We believe management’s strategy to consolidate Silkair into the parent airline is a wise decision. They have done this before with merger of Tigerair into Scoot with great success. This will create clear demarcation between the premium and budget segment.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: We expect traffic growth momentum to slow going forward due to market maturity and based on management’s latest growth plans.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: SIA has hedged up to 46% of its fuel needs up to FY23 at reasonable levels (USD57-64/bbl Brent), which provides some cost stability and lowers operating risk.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Our revised earnings forecasts are now above consensus. We think the market has not priced in SIA’s operational resilience and the benefit of a lower fuel-price environment. Furthermore, we are optimistic its efforts to consolidate operations will yield cost reductions.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Its dividend yields of > 4% are also attractive and above peer average.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Traffic growth was healthy

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Passengers carried by the Group grew by 6.3% y-o-y to 9.3m in 3QFY19. This is above its long-term average of 5% growth (excluding the Tigerair acquisition y-o-y comparison), which suggests passenger traffic growth was very healthy.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: The growth in cargo carried shrunk marginally by 0.6% y-o-y in 3QFY19.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Load factor

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: The Group passenger load factor grew by 0.7ppt y-o-y to 82.8% in 3QFY19 (Oct-Dec 2018).

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Cargo load factor was down by 2.3ppt y-o-y to 66.0% in 3QFY19. The cargo segment performed exceptionally well over the past three years but there has been a noticeable decline in 3QFY19’s performance.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Yields close to bottoming, in our view

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Passenger yield has been on a persistent downtrend and it’s currently hovering at 15% lower than its historical average yield of SG11.8 cents/km. Cargo yield however staged a recovery back in FY17 and is currently hovering above its historical average yield of SG31 cents/ton.km.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Time To Be Positive, Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Historical observations suggest that passenger yield tends to track cargo yield movement with a 2-3 year lag. If this trend repeats itself, it would suggest that the passenger yield downtrend is close to bottoming and could stage a recovery.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: Singapore Airlines - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: We expect SIA’s upcoming results release on 14 Feb to be unexciting, as the headwinds experienced in 2Q continued to persist until end-CY18.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: Having said that, the outlook for FY20F has improved due to weaker jet fuel prices, and we upgrade our core net profit forecasts accordingly.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: Maintain HOLD with a slightly higher target price of S$10.25, still based on 0.9x CY19F P/BV, 1 s.d. below mean since 2001.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L) delivered 2QFY19 core net profit that was 40% lower y-o-y on the back of higher oil prices, and the depreciation of the A$, €, and £ where SIA is net long, and the appreciation of the US$, where SIA is net short. These factors more than offset stronger cargo earnings, and masked SIA mainline’s and Scoot’s successful revenue management efforts (that raised revenue per unit of ASK capacity by lowering ticket prices to stimulate an elastic demand response).

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: During the Oct-Dec 2018 quarter, we estimate that SIA’s all-in jet fuel prices (inclusive of hedging gains) averaged US$82/bbl, which was higher than the US$72/bbl average in 3QFY18 and also higher than the US$80/bbl of the immediately preceding 2QFY19.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: While spot oil prices had dropped sharply from early-Oct 2018, airlines’ jet fuel prices generally lag by one month, so the average for 3QFY19 captured the steep rise in spot oil prices during Sep 2018. Also, the currency trends seen during 2QFY19 continued to play out during 3QFY19. As such, we expect SIA’s core net profit to be weaker y-o-y.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: In addition, SIA may report start-up losses for its non-stop A350-900ULR flights to Newark, Los Angeles and San Francisco, which started in Oct and Nov 2018. Initial promotional fares are likely loss-making, and the premium economy cabin saw low take-up in the initial period.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: Furthermore, Scoot saw its load factor drop 3.6% pts y-o-y in 3QFY19F, the first time in seven quarters, which may be partially due to the negative demand reaction from the hike in the Changi airport tax from 1 Jul 2018.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: Finally, the cargo business saw the volume of weight carried contract y-o-y for the first time in six quarters, with a larger drop during the month of Dec 2018, reflecting the global slowdown in GDP and trade growth and the softening of the business cycle.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: Lower oil prices should benefit earnings in 4QFY19F and FY20F, and we have cut our average FY19F all-in jet fuel price assumption from US$80.2/bbl to US$78.5/bbl, and for FY20F from US$83.4/bbl to US$76.5/bbl. The jet fuel price assumption changes have been reflected in our new core EPS estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: However, we have not reflected potential earnings enhancements from the upcoming transfer of 737-800 aircraft and routes from SilkAir to Scoot, which should enhance the profitability of the group as a whole.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY3/19F Results Likely To Be Weak
arguments: Refer to the PDF report attached for further analysis and valuation details.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) highlighted that RASK was “resilient” in Dec 18 and in 3QFY19. However, weak load factors from Scoot and cargo operations in December and 3QFY19 should impact group profitability.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: We also expect cargo traffic to decline in FY20 due to weak PMI. We believe this has not been factored in by the street.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Maintain HOLD but lower our target price from S$10.40 to S$10.20. Suggested entry level is S$9.00.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Pax load factor improved in Dec 18 and 3QFY18.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Parent airlines’ load factor for December 2018 improved for the 9th consecutive month as traffic outpaced capacity growth. The improvement in pax load factor was broad based except for the America’s due to significant capacity growth.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: 3QFY19’s load factor improved by 1.8ppt, which holds scope for improved profitability, provided yields do not falter.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: RASK said to be “resilient” throughout the quarter.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L) noted that RASK (revenue relative to seat capacity) remained resilient throughout the quarter. In 2QFY19, RASK improved by 3.1%, while yields fell 1%. For pax yields to remain at least flat y-o-y, RASK would have to rise by 2.2% in 3QFY19.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Cargo traffic declined for the third consecutive month.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Dec 18’s 3.5% y-o-y decline in cargo traffic does not come as a surprise. Slowing global trade and restocking ahead of the imposition of tariffs by the US were key factors. However, leading indicators such as weak PMI now seem to suggest that the trend of weaker cargo will accelerate into 2020. Thus, we lower our cargo traffic growth assumptions from -2.6% to -3.0% for FY19, and from -1.0% to -4.0% for FY20.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Scoot’s pax load factor has declined for two consecutive months and the carrier is likely to report a loss.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Repeated flight delays and concerns over problems with the Rolls Royce engine on the Dreamliners are likely to affect demand going forward. We thus lower our traffic growth assumptions from 16% to 14% for FY19, and by 3ppt to 12% for FY20.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Near-term headwinds: Slowing cargo traffic and weakening demand for Scoot.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Weakness in global PMI signals slower economic activity in the coming quarters. As such, we lower our cargo traffic growth assumption for FY19 from -2.6% to -3.0% and for FY20, we now assume a 4% decline vs a 1% decline previously.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: We also lower our traffic growth assumption for Scoot from 15% to 12% for FY20.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Over the medium term, SIA and other airlines could be hit by higher jet fuel costs as IMO2020 kicks in.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: The International Maritime Organisation mandates that by Jan 20, shipping companies cut marine fuel’s sulphur content to less than 0.5%. Some experts are of the view that this will result in a shortage of supply for other energy distillates, including jet fuel. We have not factored this in for FY20.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: We lower our net profit estimates by 3% to S$629m for FY19 and by 15% to S$594m for FY20 after factoring in lower cargo traffic and lower pax traffic for Scoot.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: We continue to value Singapore Airlines (SIA) on an SOTP basis, with the airline operations valued at 0.75x book value and SIA ENGINEERING CO LTD (SGX:S59) valued at S$2.70. Refer to the PDF report attached for the breakdown of SOTP.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: Our fair value is now lowered to S$10.20. Suggested entry price is $9.00.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Weak Load Factors At SIA Cargo And Scoot Likely To Dampen 3QFY19 & Full-Year Results
arguments: None.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: Raising Singapore Airlines’ FY20F and FY21F earnings by 9% and 12% respectively after factoring in lower jet fuel prices.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: There could be further earnings upside if oil prices continue to stay low; every US$1 decrease in average jet fuel price will raise Singapore Airlines’ FY20F earnings by 2.3%.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: Current valuation at just below 0.8x P/B (at -1.5 SD of its 10-year average) is an attractive entry level.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: Upgrade to BUY, Target Price S$11 (0.9x FYE Mar ‘20F P/B).

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: With the collapse of crude oil prices in November 2018, the market now expects the average cost of fuel to be lower in 2019F and 2020F. We assume an average jet fuel price (FOB Singapore) of US$82 per barrel in 2019F and US$80 per barrel in 2020F, compared to c. US$85 per barrel in 2018. Hence, even as yield improvement remains elusive, we project SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L)’s net earnings to improve by 25% y-o-y to S$930m in FYE Mar ’20.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: Our FY20F and FY21F earnings forecasts are 14.4% and 27.4% higher than consensus, and with jet fuel prices currently at US$65/bbl versus our assumption of US$82/bbl for FY20F, there could be further upside to Singapore Airlines’ earnings if oil prices stay low.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: We raise our FY19F, FY20F and FY21F estimates by 6%, 9% and 12% respectively to reflect our lower fuel cost assumption.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: SIA’s share price should re-rate if oil prices continue to remain low and earnings recover as expected.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: With earnings now poised to turnaround on the back of lower fuel costs, we see current share price as attractive for investors to buy into Singapore Airlines’ earnings recovery story.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: Raising Target Price to S$11 based on 0.9x FY20 P/BV, against a projected ROE of 6.5% for FY20F.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Timely Boost From Lower Fuel Prices
arguments: Vulnerable to demand shocks and/or fuel price increase.
