title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector - NEUTRAL

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Airlines and airport services

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Due to robust yield management strategies, SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L) mainline carrier and Scoot have seen four consecutive quarters of y-o-y increases in revenue per unit of ASK capacity (RASK), as higher load factors have more than offset yield declines. SIA’s cargo operations also continue to see strong demand and yields.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: The SIA group is also pursuing structural initiatives, like de-emphasising growth of SilkAir in favour of lower-cost Scoot. SIA has relaunched its direct, long-haul flights to the US, which will help boost its short-haul connections and enhance its network connectivity.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Capacity expansion by the Middle East and Chinese airlines has generally slowed in recent quarters, and as these carriers do not hedge fuel, we expect them to be more rational in their pricing and capacity expansion going forward. Conversely, SIA’s robust 46% fuel hedge cover until CY22F will protect the group substantially, against less-fortunate, lightly-hedged peers.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Rising middle income population supported traveling patterns. We saw this in the strong operating statistics in SATS LTD. (SGX:S58)’ latest 2QFY3/19 earnings with a 13.6% y-o-y increase in passengers handled and +4.6% y-o-y rise in flights handled (+4.6% y-o-y). Cruise Centre was the star performer with 113 ship calls handled (+242% y-o-y).

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Land transport

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Due to the optimisation and renewal of its taxi fleet in Singapore, COMFORTDELGRO CORPORATION LTD (SGX:C52) has seen three consecutive quarters of q-o-q increases in operating profit from the taxi business amid expansion of its fleet over the Jul-Sep period. Taxi idle rate remains at 2% and its fleet stood at 12,691 as at end-Sep; ComfortDelGro is expecting to take delivery of up to 700 new hybrid taxis by year-end. Total taxis in Singapore saw a net increase of 115 over the Jul-Sep period, in contrast to a net decline of 2,407 private hire cars in the same period.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: For its public transport services, ComfortDelGro continued to see y-o-y increases in operating profit over the past six consecutive quarters amid higher ridership across all of its rail services – North East Line (NEL), Sengkang-Punggol LRT (SPLRT) and Downtown Line (DTL) – with the newer DTL’s average daily ridership registering an 82.9% y-o-y increase to 472k passenger trips during the Jul-Sep 18 quarter. The Public Transport Council has also approved a 4.3% hike in rail fares that will take effect by year-end after three consecutive years of fare declines, which should translate into an increase of S$10.9m in train revenue for ComfortDelGro.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Airlines and airport services

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Changi Airport raised the passenger service charge (PSC) by S$13.30 effective 1 Jul 2018, representing a 2.5% hike in SIA mainline’s average fares, a 5.6% hike for SilkAir, and a 7% hike for Scoot. Long-haul flights should be immune to this, but demand for short-haul and LCC flights could be impacted, and make it more difficult for the SIA group to pass on higher jet fuel prices. We expect oil prices to rise over the next two years due to the effects of the International Maritime Organization’s global sulphur cap on marine fuels that will take effect from 1 Jan 2020; this has the potential to hurt SIA’s bottomline.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: IATA recently highlighted that growth in global air passenger demand and airfreight demand has been slowing down, commensurate with the slowdown in global Purchasing Managers Index (PMI). Also, we expect the potential losses from SIA’s launch of direct ultra long-haul (ULR) flights to the US to be visible from 4QCY18F onwards, although they remain strategically critical to SIA.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: SATS has started to feel the pressure from trade tension as cargo volumes for emerging markets and in/out of China slowed down. Weakening currency from India and Indonesia also eroded some of its associates’ profits.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Our airlines analyst, Raymond Yap, is taking a more bullish view on jet fuel prices, which we assume to average US$85/bbl in CY18F, rise to US$90/bbl in CY19F, and to US$95/bbl in CY20F, driven up by US sanctions on Iranian oil exports and by the upcoming IMO 2020 implementation. This is expected to be partially offset by assumed increases in base ticket prices, but this may not fully recover the higher fuel costs. However, the outlook for SIA may be made more challenging in CY20F due to the softening global growth outlook, as indicated by the sequentially declining global Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) and the new export orders of the global PMI.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: For ComfortDelGro, we see robust earnings growth in FY19F (+13% y-o-y), underpinned by stronger earnings from both the taxi and public transport services segments. Notwithstanding Go-JEK entering the private-hire car (PHC) fray but under a more regulated ride-hailing space and given that Uber has exited Southeast Asia after sparking an unsustainable price war, we believe the worst is over for ComfortDelGro’s taxi business. Public transport services should continue to grow, supported by a 4.3% hike in rail fares and overseas acquisitions.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Declining growth in trade could also post softness in freights handled by SATS. In the longer term, alternative trade routes into/out of ASEAN (such as Vietnam) could mitigate this, but we do not expect this to take place in the next 12 months.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: We downgrade the overall transport sector to NEUTRAL from Overweight, following our recent downgrade of SIA to HOLD (see report: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Risks To Watch Out For).

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: Our target price for SIA is at S$10.10, based on 0.9x CY19F P/BV, which is at -1 s.d. of its P/BV mean since 2001, as we do not think that investors will be motivated to bid up the share price given the prevailing tough conditions. We do believe, however, that SIA is intrinsically worth at least 1x P/BV over the long term, as the airline group continues to be profitable despite very tough competitive conditions, and continues to invest in its products, services and network that keeps it at, or near, the top of its peers in every way imaginable.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: ComfortDelGro is our preferred pick in the transport sector with an ADD call on the stock. Our target price of S$2.74 is based on DCF valuation (WACC: 7.4%; LTG: 2%) which implies 18x CY19F P/E. At 14x 12M forward P/E, below its 10-year historical average of 16x, its valuation appears undemanding, in our view.

title: Navigate Singapore 2019 ~ Transport Sector  - NEUTRAL
analyst: Raymond YAP  [CFA] | Colin TAN  | LIM Siew Khee
arguments: We have a HOLD call on SATS with a Target Price of S$5.06, based on 20x CY19F P/E (3-year mean). Re-rating catalysts could come from sizeable earnings-accretive M&As. At c.19x CY19F, the stock appears fairly traded with potential risks from further devaluation of emerging market currency and weaker-than-expected cargo handling volume as a result of trade tension.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: SG Industrial Stocks - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Conglomerates/ Offshore & Marine yards – few big orders despite higher oil price.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Transport – only ComfortDelgro is up YTD.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Prefer ST Engineering (STE) and Singapore Airlines (SIA).

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: 2018 – a year of realisation for some

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Our year-end report for the Oil and Gas sector last year was titled “Awaiting contract wins”, in which we expected a gradual recovery in 2018 and mentioned that a re-rating of stocks in the sector would require a continued flow of contract wins. We recall that there was significant excitement in the market in the earlier part of this year, with great expectations for new order wins especially for Sembcorp Marine (SGX:S51) (along with speculation of a possible merger), but both disappointed as we cruised through the year. This is despite crude prices continuing their upward climb till end Sep, before dropping steadily in the last two months or so.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: We believe a clear point of realization for some erst-while bulls came in mid Jul when Sembcorp Marine’s management mentioned that the group’s transformation efforts to move up the value chain has resulted in new business opportunities but they require significant time and effort in project co-development with potential customers. Such new-build EPC projects have detailed engineering and construction planning phase, which may take as long as six to 12 months before main construction activities and corresponding revenue recognition can take place.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: This year, our Singapore Industrials sector report comprises two key segments that are affected by movements in the oil price – the Conglomerates/ Offshore & Marine yards as well as the Transport segment.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Mostly in line with broader STI except for STE, SMM and YZJ

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Stocks in the sub-sector mostly traded in line with the broader STI with the exception of ST Engineering (SGX:S63), Sembcorp Marine (SGX:S51) and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (SGX:BS6).

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: ST Engineering (STE) saw consistently good stock price performance in general this year with healthy earnings and the announcement of the largest acquisition in history which is a strategic fit for the company. We upgraded our rating on the stock to BUY in early Feb this year. See recent report: ST Engineering - Well-placed For Long Term Growth.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Sembcorp Marine (SMM), in comparison, saw a roller-coaster ride in the earlier part of this year due to excitement over potential new orders and a merger talk between itself and Keppel, only to correct subsequently when nothing significant materialised. New order flows have also disappointed so far this year. Since the start of this year, our rating has been a HOLD for the stock. See recent report: Sembcorp Marine - Not Much Of A Surprise.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (YZJ)’s stock was also volatile, falling about 43% from the beginning of this year to its trough in mid Jul, before rising by about 48% to current levels. We upgraded the stock in BUY in mid Jun, before downgrading to HOLD in early Oct. In early Nov post 3Q18 results, we upgraded the stock to BUY again. See recent report: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding - Come Onboard Again.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Mostly in line with broader STI except for ComfortDelgro, SIAEC

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Stocks in the sub-sector mostly traded in line with the broader STI as well, with the exception of ComfortDelgro (SGX:C52), and SIA Engineering (SGX:S59) in the last few weeks.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: The stock price of ComfortDelgro rallied in Apr/May this year with the exit of Uber from Singapore, but has softened in recent times with the impending entry of Go-Jek, along with weakness in the broader market. Our rating for ComfortDelgro was upgraded to Buy in mid Feb before it was downgraded to HOLD in early Jun. See recent report: ComfortDelGro - Monitoring The Taxi Space.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments:
As for SIA Engineering (SIAEC), it has broadly tracked the market so far this year, except for a recent fall in share price post the release of its 2QFY19 results and our rating downgrade to HOLD on 9 Nov. See recent report: SIA Engineering - Headwinds And Some Turbulence. Headwinds for the company remain and we see few catalysts for now, except for

less pricing pressure from airlines under a lower oil price environment, or
a possible privatisation by SIA (SGX:C6L).

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: less pricing pressure from airlines under a lower oil price environment, or

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: a possible privatisation by SIA (SGX:C6L).

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: OIL PRICES - Brent closed at US$86/bbl in early Oct 2018

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: With rising global oil demand and production cuts by OPEC, the crude oil glut that we saw in 2014 has narrowed substantially into a mild under-supply scenario in the 12 months leading to Apr 2018 before a balance was seen subsequently.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Brent crude closed at its highest level in four years in early Oct, settling at more than US$86/bbl for the first time since Oct 2014.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: OCBC and Bank of Singapore stuck to their guns

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Crude oil, being a highly liquid exchange traded product that is susceptible to speculative trading, tends to overshoot on the upside as well as on the downside in the near term. OCBC Treasury Research and Strategy as well as Bank of Singapore (BOS) sounded caution when it looked as if the crude market was getting overheated, arguing on the basis of fundamentals.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: When certain banks increased their forecasts during crude’s upward march in the middle of this year (only to decrease after Oct), both OCBC and BOS stood by their forecasts ranging from US$60-70/bbl for end 2018. Indeed from early Oct onwards, both Brent and WTI crude have tumbled by about 30% since.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Looking ahead, OCBC is forecasting WTI to average US$65 in 4Q19, and Brent at US$70. BOS is forecasting WTI and Brent at $60 and $65 12 months out from mid Nov 2018.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: US – making history by exceeding 11m bbl/day for the first time

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: According to the US Energy Information Administration (EIA), US crude oil production reached 11.3m bbl/day in Aug 2018 – the first time that monthly US production levels surpassed 11m bbl/day. The growth in Texas and New Mexico production since the start of 2018 surpassed EIA’s previous expectations, which assumed that pipeline capacity constraints in the Permian region would dampen production growth. However, industry efficiencies in pipeline utilisation and increased trucking and tail transport in the region have allowed crude oil production to continue to grow at a higher rate than expected.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Over the past 10 years, US crude oil production has increased significantly (Exhibit 5 in the PDF report attached), driven mainly by production from tight oil formations using horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing. EIA estimates of crude oil production from tight formations in Aug 2018 reached 6.2m bbl/day, or 55% of the national total.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: US - now the world’s top crude producer; upside supply risks remain

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: The US crude oil production of 11.3m bbl/day in Aug was also more than the Russian Ministry of Energy’s estimated Aug production of 11.2m bbl/day, making the US the leading crude oil producer in the world. The oil price decline in mid 2014 resulted in US producers reducing their costs and temporarily scaling back production. However, after crude oil prices increased in early 2016, investment and production began increasing later that year. In comparison, Russia and Saudi Arabia have maintained relatively steady crude oil production growth in recent years.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Looking ahead, EIA forecasts US crude oil production to increase by 1.0m bbl/day in 2019, and we see upside supply risks which may cap the upside on oil prices.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Overall, the utilisation rate of marketed rigs has continued to increase this year, and is now hovering slightly under 75%. Supply of marketed rigs has decreased slightly, while supply of the entire rig fleet has fallen to a greater degree with scrapping of older units.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: However, for a better idea of the outlook for our local yards, it is useful to drill down and look at the three main rig segments in turn – jack-ups, semi-submersibles and drillships.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: After declining significantly in 2014-2016, utilisation rates for harsh environment jack-ups in NW Europe saw stabilization in 2017 before recovering this year, such that current utilisation rates hover around 65- 70% (Exhibit 9). Utilisation has to increase more first before we can see a recovery in day rates. This has been one of the segments that Keppel Corp (SGX:BN4) and Sembcorp Marine have been focused on, and a continued recovery may herald better news for both companies. In comparison, the shallow water jack-ups in the SE Asia region (Exhibit 8 in the PDF report attached) did not see a recovery unlike the NW Europe harsh environment jack-ups.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: For ultra-deepwater semi-submersibles (Exhibit 10 in the PDF report attached), the utilization rate remains low at around 35%, and average day rates remain low as well. Unlike other rig types, this segment has not seen an uptick in utilisation rates.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: As for the drillship segment (Exhibit 11 in the PDF report attached), utilisation levels seem to have found a bottom in 2017, and there has been an uptick in 2018. The recovery is likely to be a very gradual one, which is not surprising given that the deep-water space is usually lagging in the recovery process.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: The transport sector is very much affected by oil prices as well, due to fuel costs. However, the extent varies as well. ComfortDelgro’s business segments include public transport operations, and fare adjustments are also tied to fuel costs as well, to either contain the upside or compensate ComfortDelgro when fuel costs swing.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: In comparison, fuel costs affect airlines to a greater extent, but it also depends on the amount of hedges that the airline uses. In 1HFY19, fuel costs (post hedging) accounted for 30% of SIA’s total costs. For 2HFY19, SIA has hedged 58% of its fuel requirements in MOPS (jet fuel) at a weighted average price of US$71, against the current MOPS price of US$87. For FY20, 52% is hedged with 17% at US$79 on average for jet fuel) and 35% at US$56 on average for Brent.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Outlook for transport-related names

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Oil prices aside, we expect ComfortDelgro (SGX:C52)’s growth to be driven by overseas acquisitions, supported by stable operating cash flows from public transport operations in Singapore. So far this year, the group has invested about S$450m in overseas acquisitions, mainly in Australia. As for its taxi operations, the market is likely to focus on the actions that Go-Jek would take in its entry to Singapore. Should an aggressive pricing strategy be pursued, sentiment on the stock may be affected. We estimate that the Singapore taxi business accounts for about 20-25% of operating income for the group.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: For SIA (SGX:C6L), passenger load factors should remain strong on robust passenger growth, but passenger yields may be capped by intense competition from rival airlines. For 2HFY19, earnings should improve on weaker oil prices. Over the longer term, this is a capital intensive business and significant capital expenditure is expected, and we forecast an increase in net gearing for the group.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: SIA Engineering

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: SIA Engineering (SGX:S59), in which SIA owns a 77.7% stake, faces some issues in the meantime. Aircraft are spending a longer time in the hangars than before, meaning missed opportunities to undertake maintenance work for other aircraft. The number of checks that can be undertaken is constrained by hangar capacity, so there may be a limit to growth unless the group comes up with creative solutions or new income streams.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: SATS Ltd

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: SATS (SGX:S58) has been steadily increasing its dividends over the years since FY13, backed by an average 6-7% earnings growth per year. We believe there is ample cushion for dividends to be sustained, and sufficient room for investments as well.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Post our downgrade on 9 Nov and the release of its 2QFY19 results, the share price of SATS Ltd has dropped by 9.1% compared to the STI’s 0.2% fall over the same period, based on the closing price on 28 Nov. Recall that results were in line with our expectations, with 1H18 net profit accounting for 51% of our full year figure.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: We had downgraded our rating for SATS due to the limited upside potential post share price appreciation, but now with the recent correction, value is emerging again. We are now upgrading to BUY with a slightly lower Fair Value estimate of S$5.34 (prev S$5.39).

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Gradual recovery in 2019; continued flow of orders needed

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Looking ahead in 2019, we expect the offshore oil and gas sector to continue its gradual recovery, underpinned by cost deflation across the industry and lower break evens. Orders are still mainly expected from the non-drilling segment as recovery in the drilling market will still take time. However, should there be significant contract wins in 2019 for Keppel Corp (SGX:BN4) and Sembcorp Marine, we see chances for trading opportunities especially for the latter.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: A sustained recovery, however, will only ensue with a continued flow of contract wins, which will drive a re-rating of related stocks in the sector.

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Preferred picks – STE and SIA

title: SG Industrial Stocks  - Opt For Resilience & Low Valuations
arguments: Among the Singapore Industrials space, we prefer ST Engineering (STE) [Rating: BUY; Fair Value: S$3.95] with its earnings resilience, backed by a stable and diversified order book across industries (aerospace, electronics, land systems and marine), and Singapore Airlines (SIA) [Rating: BUY; Fair Value: S$10.71] due to its low valuations and a softer oil price environment which should lend near-term support to earnings.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport - Pick The Right Seat

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: We like ComfortDelGro (BUY, Target Price S$2.56) as its earnings revert back to growth and also ST Engineering (BUY, S$4.15) for its robust profit growth prospects.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: Higher oil prices and trade war concerns will weigh on Singapore Airlines (HOLD) and HPH Trust (HOLD); SIA Engineering (HOLD) faces margin pressure.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: For air travel growth proxies, we like SATS (BUY, Target Price S$5.60) and China Aviation Oil (BUY, Target Price S$1.90).

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: HOLD call for SIA (Target Price S$10.20) as yield expansion lags fuel cost increase.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: SINGAPORE AIRLINES LTD (SGX:C6L) recently reported 2Q19 earnings that were below our expectations, as passenger yield for the flagship segment declined for a second consecutive quarter despite strong load factors. With fuel prices at a substantially higher level currently, passenger yields need to improve for Singapore Airlines to post returns that are equal to or better than its cost of capital, but this could be a challenging task for SIA given the ongoing stiff competition and US-China trade war situation, which is also beginning to affect the larger global economy.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: We would turn positive on Singapore Airlines if crude oil prices fall to US$65/bbl and below and hold without travel demand being affected.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: SATS (BUY, Target Price S$5.60) to ride on Changi’s long term growth.

analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]

arguments: more positive outlook from TFK Japan – with Japan aiming to grow the number of tourists to 40m pax by 2020 and 60m pax by 2040.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: CAO (BUY, Target Price S$1.90) is a more attractive proxy for air travel growth.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: We still like CHINA AVIATION OIL(S) CORP LTD (SGX:G92) given its monopolistic position as the sole importer of bonded jet fuel into China, and for its 33% stake in the exclusive jet fueller SPIA at Shanghai Pudong International Airport.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: China Aviation Oil has lost over 22% since the start of the year even though its 9MFY18 earnings rose by c.8%. It is now trading at an attractive FY18 PE of 8.4x and FY19 PE of 7.6x.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: BUY call (Target Price S$4.15) for ST Engineering on robust growth prospects.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments:
We like SINGAPORE TECH ENGINEERING LTD (SGX:S63) for a combination of factors:

strong inorganic growth potential from acquisition in the Aerospace segment,
recovery in engine MRO demand and in the longer-term, sizeable contribution from Airbus P2F programmes currently in ramp-up phase,
growing smart city revenues,
remaining in the hunt for potential large contract awards in the US in the future, ranging from postal service trucks to army tanks, and
good progress in the fields of logistics automation and systems integration for electric and autonomous vehicles.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: Revenue and margin pressure persists for SIA Engineering, HOLD (Target Price S$2.94).

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: SIA ENGINEERING CO LTD (SGX:S59) continues to face structural headwinds in the form of OEM encroachment in the aftermarket space, longer heavy maintenance cycles for newer aircraft models and keen competition from emerging lower-cost regional competitors. SIA Engineering’s core operating business saw lower utilisation and pricing pressure that eroded its margins in its interim results and we expect core EBIT margins to remain range bound at 4%-5%.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: With FY19 earnings likely to fall y-o-y and flat dividends at best, we reckon SIA Engineering would not be seen as a safe-haven stock in current volatile market conditions, and recommend looking at ST Engineering instead for a better growth-cum-yield story.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: BUY (Target Price S$2.18) for ComfortDelGro as earnings start to recover.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments:
We project COMFORTDELGRO CORPORATION LTD (SGX:C52)’s earnings to register y-o-y growth from 4Q18 onwards, and going into FY19F. This is on the back of:

bottoming out in taxi fleet contraction in Singapore;
earnings contribution from recent acquisitions; and
public transport fare increase of 4.3% effective 29 December 2018.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: bottoming out in taxi fleet contraction in Singapore;

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: earnings contribution from recent acquisitions; and

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: public transport fare increase of 4.3% effective 29 December 2018.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: As can be seen in its 3Q18 results, while still registering y-o-y declines in profits, the 2Q18 decline is of a smaller magnitude vs 1Q/2Q18, thus indicating sequential improvement. ComfortDelGro also provides a yield of 4.8%/5.2% for FY18F/19F, which we believe is relatively attractive.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: HPH Trust continues to disappoint (HOLD, Target Price US$0.24).

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments:
We are neutral on HUTCHISON PORT HOLDINGS TRUST (SGX:NS8U) despite what seems like an attractive yield of 8.5% for FY18 (declining to 7.5% for FY19), as we anticipate its Hong Kong operations will struggle to improve its profitability significantly. Key challenges include:

the formation of larger shipping alliances being able to negotiate better terms, and
competition remaining stiff in the transshipment business, while the ongoing US-China trade war would further pose a threat to the Trust, whose volumes are entirely derived from the Pearl River Delta, China’s main export region.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: the formation of larger shipping alliances being able to negotiate better terms, and

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: competition remaining stiff in the transshipment business, while the ongoing US-China trade war would further pose a threat to the Trust, whose volumes are entirely derived from the Pearl River Delta, China’s main export region.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: Significantly higher oil prices would impact SIA and HPH Trust directly.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: Fuel costs (after hedging) currently account for c.30% of Singapore Airlines’ operating costs while we estimate that energy costs account for about 15% of HPH Trust’s total operating costs. As such, a further increase in fuel prices would pressure the margins of both these players, especially when considering that they both do not have significant pricing power. However, should oil prices fall significantly, this will help Singapore Airlines and HPH Trust.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: Stronger demand from a pick-up in economic activity could help lift earnings across the sector.

title: 2019 Outlook & Strategy ~ Transport  - Pick The Right Seat
analyst: Paul YONG  [CFA] | Suvro SARKAR  | Andy SIM  [CFA]
arguments: A better-than-expected economic growth and activity globally would help improve demand volume and pricing for the transport sector. This should in turn help enhance ROEs, for the last few years.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Singapore Airlines - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: SIA’s 1HFY19 operating profit 47% of full year.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Interim dividend of S$0.08/share.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: 58% of fuel hedged for 2HFY19.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 5.6% y-o-y rise in revenue to S$4.1b in 2QFY19 and net profit of S$56.4m, impacted by S$117.1m share of losses of associated companies. This was mainly due to the recognition of SIA’s share of loss from Virgin Australia, which we had highlighted in our earlier report on 17 Oct.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: 1HFY19 revenue and operating profit were 49% and 47% of our full year estimates, within expectations.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Operating profit was 44% y-o-y lower, but if one-off items were to be excluded, it would be 27% lower, mainly due to higher fuel costs.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Flown revenue rose by S$422m, contributed by passenger flown revenue (+S$346m or +5.8%) and cargo flown revenue (S$76m or +7.4%).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Passenger flown revenue was lifted by an 8.8% increase in traffic, outpacing growth in capacity of 5.4%, driving passenger load factor to rise 2.6% points to 83.6%.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Passenger unit revenue (in revenue per available seat-km) grew 1.3% as transformation efforts yielded positive results.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Bookings in the coming months are expected to be stronger y-o-y, but headwinds continue to persist in the form of cost pressures arising from elevated fuel prices and keen competition.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: For 2HFY19, SIA has hedged 58% of its fuel requirements in MOPS (jet fuel) at a weighted average price of US$71, against the current MOPS price of US$87.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: For FY20, 52% is hedged with 17% at US$79 on average for jet fuel) and 35% at US$56 on average for Brent.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Looking ahead, the projected capacity growth (in ASK) for FY88 vs. FY88 is 8% for SIA, 8% for SilkAir, 88% for Scoot and 8% for the whole group. For cargo, it is expected to be flat (in CTK).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Singapore Airlines has declared an interim dividend of S$8.88/share, compared to S$8.88/share a year ago, which is not a surprise to us – our FY88 dividend forecast remains at S$8.88 compared to S$8.88 in FY88.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Impacted By Virgin AU As Expected
arguments: Meanwhile, valuations remain low at about 8.88x forward P/B. We maintain our Fair Value estimate of S$88.88.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: SIA’s 1HFY3/19 core net profit was in-line at 50% of our full-year estimate, but underperformed consensus at only 38% of the street’s FY19F forecast.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: We remain HOLD, with an unchanged target price of S$10.10, still based on 0.9x CY19F P/BV, 1 s.d. below mean since 2001.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: SIA's share price may drop further today. During the 2008 GFC, SIA hit bottom at 0.75-0.8x P/BV, implying strong support at S$8.50-S$9.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: SIA group’s 2QFY19 core net profit of S$168m was 40% lower y-o-y as the operating profit of SIA mainline fell on account of higher oil prices, while SilkAir and Scoot both suffered quarterly operating losses against profits a year earlier, all of which more than offset the ongoing strength in cargo earnings, which has achieved eight consecutive quarters of y-o-y improvement.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: On a reported net profit level, SIA’s 2QFY19 was very weak at just S$56m, as SIA took up its S$116m share of Virgin Australia’s asset impairment and deferred tax write-off, which the 20.1%-owned associate had reported in its Jun 2018 quarter results.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: In previous oil price upcycles, SIA has typically struggled to fully pass on higher fuel costs due to strong competition in the Asian landscape, and in order to maintain passenger load factors as high as possible.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: SIA’s financial results in the past year show that the prevailing wisdom remains intact. Having said that, SIA’s new revenue management system and philosophy of maximising revenue per unit of ASK capacity (RASK) has shown results, as the mainline carrier’s and Scoot’s RASK metrics have risen y-o-y for four consecutive quarters, with yields deliberately reduced to stimulate a strong demand uptick in price-elastic markets and produce growth in total revenue. Unfortunately, cost per ASK (CASK) has risen more rapidly than RASK, masking SIA’s revenue efforts.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: SIA’s calculated gamble with rapid SilkAir expansion over the past 3½ years did not deliver the returns that SIA had hoped for, in our view, as competition with LCCs in Southeast Asia capped SilkAir’s pricing power, and prevented it from growing its demand base without significantly compromising yields.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: SilkAir’s yields have declined y-o-y for the past 12 quarters, and alarmingly, RASK has also continued to decline over that same period, which is a clear indication of significant overcapacity in the price range that SilkAir occupies.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: Half of SilkAir’s current fleet may eventually be transferred to Scoot.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: As we explained in our recent 12 Nov note: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Risks To Watch Out For, we expect Brent crude oil prices to rise in CY20F as a result of the IMO 2020 implementation, with jet fuel crack spreads to widen against historical averages.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: SIA’s efforts to pass on higher fuel costs will be made more challenging by higher Changi airport taxes, a weakening business cycle, and investment losses for the new A350-900ULR direct, non-stop flights to the US.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: Better-than-expected outcome from the restructuring of SilkAir, continuing efforts in revenue management that may help to further improve the RASK metric of SIA mainline and Scoot and more aggressive push by Asian airlines for fuel cost recovery.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Cost Inflation Undercuts Good Yield Management
arguments: Potential faster-than-expected increase in oil prices if Iranian production is reduced rapidly due to US sanctions, high degree of compliance with IMO 8888 requirements that may cause a surge in demand for marine gasoil (the impact of which will spill over to other middle distillate products like jet fuel).

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: SIA's 2Q19 EBIT falls 35% y-o-y to S$233m on higher fuel costs and lower passenger yield - below expectations.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: Including share of one-off losses of S$116m at associate Virgin Australia, interim profit fell 69% y-o-y to S$196m; interim DPS cut by 20% to 8Scts.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: We cut FY19F/20F EPS estimates by 31%/23%.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: Downgrade to HOLD with Target Price of S$10.20.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: SIA reported 2Q19 earnings that were below our expectations as passenger yield for the flagship segment declined 1% y-o-y and one-off share of losses at associate Virgin Australia led to 81% decline in net profit for the quarter to S$56.4m, with interim earnings falling by 81% y-o-y to just S$196m.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: Meanwhile, the Group also cut its interim dividend from 10Scts to 8Scts.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: We lower our FY19F and FY20F estimates by 31% and 23% respectively to reflect lower passenger yield assumptions and the one-off losses at Virgin Australia, and expect consensus to also cut forecasts.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: SIA’s share price could re-rate on the back of yield recovery, sustained improvement in revenues, and ongoing cost management initiatives to lower its costs.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: More significant passenger yield improvement is needed for core earnings to rebound. With fuel prices at a substantially higher level currently, passenger yields need to improve for SIA to post returns equal or better than its cost of capital.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: Meanwhile, SIA’s transformation program has started to bear fruit as non-fuel costs across all segments have fallen and further gains from the program could help to alleviate cost pressures and further optimise revenues.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: Lowering Target Price to S$88.88 based on 8.88x FY88 P/BV, against a projected ROE of 8.8%.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: We cut our DPS forecast from 88Scts to 88Scts, translating to 8.8% prospective yield for the stock.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: Vulnerable to demand shocks and/or fuel price increase. With operating margins at razor thin levels, SIA is vulnerable to any demand shocks and/or an increase in fuel prices.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: EBIT declined even as revenues improved in 8Q88:

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: SIA's 8Q88 group revenue increased 8.8% y-o-y to S$8.88bn on higher carriage across all its key segments but EBIT fell by 88% y-o-y to S$888m as fuel costs rose by 88% y-o-y to S$8,888m. Non-fuel costs rose at a slower pace than revenue growth at 8.8% y-o-y.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: EBIT declined for SIA’s flagship passenger segment by 88% y-o-y to S$888m while both Silkair (-S$8m) and Scoot (- S$88m) slipped into losses during the quarter.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: 8Q net profit falls to just S$88m on share of losses at Virgin Australia:

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: Including its share of one-off losses (due to major accounting adjustments) at associate Virgin Australia of S$888m, profit for the quarter fell by 88% y-o-y to just S$88.8m.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: Interim earnings lower by 88% y-o-y to S$888m.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: As at half-time, EBIT fell by 88% y-o-y to S$888m despite revenues improving by 8.8% y-o-y to S$8.8bn. This was mainly due to fuel costs (after hedging) rising by 88% y-o-y and 8% y-o-y decline in yield for its flagship passenger airline segment.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Passenger Yield Fails To Improve
arguments: We lower our FY88F and FY88F estimates by 88% and 88% respectively to reflect lower passenger yield assumptions and the one-off losses at Virgin Australia.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - 2QFY19: Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Core earnings, excluding the recognition of deferred tax asset write down for Virgin Australia, was S$47m better than expected. The street however had not factored this in.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: While we are slightly disappointed with the 2% decline in pax yields, we are encouraged by SIA's optimism on cargo outlook for the near term.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: We also believe that SIA will continue to benefit from lower fuel prices, and margins could improve in 3QFY19.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: We recommend accumulating the stock at S$9.20-9.30. Maintain HOLD. Target: S$10.40.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: 2QFY19 net profit of S$56m beats our estimate of S$10m loss but was lower than street’s estimate of S$147m in profits.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: The earnings miss from consensus standpoint was primarily due to the fact the street had not factored in losses from 20%-owned Virgin Australia. We estimated S$137m in EI charge for the latter, arising from a A$456m de-recognition of deferred tax assets. The number was S$21m lower at S$116m.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Excluding that, 2Q's net profit was S$47m better than expected. This was in turn due to better profits at the parent airlines.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Effective 1QFY19, SIA had combined the parent airline's pax earnings together with cargo operations, and we suspect that cargo earnings were very strong due to strong yields (+9.7% y-o-y).

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: SIA also recognised S$152m in fuel hedging gains.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: The carrier however, cut interim dividend by 2 S cents to 8 S cents.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: SIA's pax yield weakened by 2% y-o-y while revenue per seat km (RASK) rose 1.2% y-o-y in 2QFY19.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: This again was below expectation as we had assumed a 1% decline for the quarter. Pax yield declined the most in August, falling 3%, before recovering in September. RASK however was higher throughout the months.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Cargo yields however rose 9.7% y-o-y and is likely to be a key reason for the better-than-expected operating profit at the parent airline.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Airline subsidiaries fared poorly.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Silk Air and Scoot reported operating losses of S$3m and S$11m respectively, as higher fuel cost offset the increase in revenue.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Amid a broad-based decline in parent airline, Silk Air's yield fell 7% y-o-y and Scoot’s yields were flat. Silk Air's weak yields could indicate that regional routes are likely to be oversupplied.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: SIA is optimistic on near-term outlook for air cargo

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: The carrier stated that notwithstanding global trade tensions, cargo demand is expected to remain healthy in the near term.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: SIA has hedged 58% of jet fuel requirements for 2HFY19 at US$71/bbl vs current price of US$87/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Neutral on the results.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: While core net profit was better than expected, we believe this was mainly due to strong cargo profitability.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: While SIA is optimistic on the cargo earnings in the near term,  we believe that cargo yields and volume are likely to weaken by 1Q19 as semiconductor and handphone shipments are expected to decline. Y-o-y improvement in yields are likely to be significantly lower in the coming quarters too, due to a high base and potentially weak demand.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Buy the dips.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: In the event that SIA's stock price declines in early trade, we recommend clients to accumulate near S$9.20-9.30. 2QFY19's results reflect a period of rising fuel costs. Jet fuel prices have weakened since then and Brent crude prices have weakened despite Saudi Arabia's plans to cut production. This reflects concerns over weakening demand.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: In its guidance on outlook, SIA noted that forward bookings are higher for the immediate months and thus there is a possibility of higher pax yields.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: There is no change to our earnings estimates for now, but we will revise our estimates pending updates from the analyst briefing.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: We maintain our target price of S$10.40, which is based on 0.75x FY19's book value.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: At current price of S$9.42, SIA is trading at 0.65x FY19's book value. Maintain HOLD.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - 2QFY19 Beats Expectations On Stronger-Than-Expected Cargo Yields
arguments: Weakening fuel prices.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Risks To Watch Out For

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: We downgrade Singapore Airlines (SIA) from Add to HOLD on multiple risks to earnings, including the hike in airport taxes, and forecast for higher oil prices due to IMO 2020.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Our target price is cut to S$10.10, based on 0.9x CY19F P/BV, 1 std dev below the mean since 2001 vs. 1.05x previously, approximately the mean.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: SIA is intrinsically worth at least 1x P/BV due to continuing investments to product, service and network, but investors are unlikely to pay for it right now.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Can the SIA group pass through higher airport charges?

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Changi Airport raised the passenger service charge (PSC) by S$13.30 effective 1 July 2018, representing a 2.5% hike in SIA mainline’s average fares, a 5.6% hike for SilkAir, and a 7% hike for Scoot.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Long-haul flights should be immune to this, but demand for short-haul and LCC flights could be impacted, and make it more difficult for the SIA group to pass on higher jet fuel prices.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Can higher jet fuel prices be recovered?

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Asian airlines have resisted pressure to raise ticket prices until more recently, but we suspect that SIA will not be able recover more than 50% of the oil price increases, with the recovery rate for SilkAir and Scoot likely lower. This cost recovery will take time, as consumers will reject sudden, substantial increases, hence higher oil prices from the effects of IMO 2020 will still hurt the bottom line.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: SIA’s robust 46% fuel hedge cover until CY22F will protect the group substantially vs. less-fortunate, lightly-hedged peers.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Are currency movements helping or hurting?

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: SIA is net short the US$, which has strengthened against the S$ recently, while SIA is net long the A$, € and £ which have all depreciated against the S$. As such, we expect recent currency movements to have deducted from SIA’s financial performance.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Is the global business cycle weakening?

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: IATA recently highlighted that the growth of global air passenger RPK demand and the airfreight FTK demand has been slowing, commensurate with the slowdown of the global PMI.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: In SIA group’s case, the global slowdown does not seem apparent for now, due to the strong growth of SilkAir and Scoot, but if global demand momentum slows further, competition between airlines may become more severe, and the SIA group may find it more difficult to sustain its RASK-maximisation strategy.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Is competition becoming stronger?

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: The capacity expansion by the Middle East and Chinese airlines has generally slowed in recent quarters, and without fuel hedges, we expect them to be more rational in their pricing and capacity expansion going forward.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: What are the promotional costs of the ULR flights?

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: We expect the potential losses from SIA’s launch of direct ULR flights to the US to be FY88F onwards, although they remain strategically critical to SIA.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Downgrade to Hold, target price lowered to S$10.10.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments:
We downgrade our recommendation on SIA from Add to HOLD, given that there are multiple risks to earnings, arising particularly from

the increase in Changi Airport’s PSC by S$88.88/pax effective 8 July 8888,
the strength in jet fuel prices over the past year,
our expectations that the implementation of the IMO 8888 global sulphur cap on marine fuels will push up crude oil prices and jet fuel crack spreads from mid-CY88 and into CY88,
the ongoing rise in the US$ in which most of SIA’s costs are denominated in,
the depreciation of SIA’s major revenue currencies such as the A$, € and £,
the global business cycle slowdown that may impact future demand for premium seats and for airfreight, and finally,
the start-up losses from the ULR flights.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: the increase in Changi Airport’s PSC by S$88.88/pax effective 8 July 8888,

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: the strength in jet fuel prices over the past year,

arguments: the start-up losses from the ULR flights.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: We have cut our FY88-88F core net profit forecasts by 88-88%, as we raise our S$:US$8 assumption from S$8.88 to S$8.88 for all forecast years, and as we raise our spot jet fuel price assumption from US$88/bbl in FY88-88F to US$88/bbl for FY88F and US$88/bbl for FY88F. This is partially offset by an assumed increase in base ticket prices, but this is not expected to fully recover the higher fuel costs.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: Our target price of S$88.88 is based on 8.8x CY88F P/BV, which is 8 standard deviation below the P/BV mean since 8888. Our previous target price of S$88.88 was based on 8.88x CY88F P/BV, which is approximately the P/BV mean. We have used a lower P/BV multiple to establish our 8-year forward target price for SIA, as we do not think that investors will be motivated to bid up the share price with the prevailing tough conditions.

title: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Risks To Watch Out For
arguments: We do believe, however, that SIA is intrinsically worth at least 8x P/BV over the long term, as the airline group continues to be profitable despite very tough competitive conditions, and continues to invest in its product, service and network that keeps it at, or near, the top of its peers in every way imaginable.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Singapore Airlines - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: We estimate a 2QFY19 (out 13 Nov) core net profit of SGD118m (-38% y-o-y, -16% q-o-q). We think yield attrition and higher jet fuel prices will weigh on its bottom line. Otherwise, the company has done a good job of raising overall loads by 1.7ppts y-o-y to 73.3%, a record since 2010.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: We raise FY19-21E earnings by 3.9-5.5% to factor in higher load factors, its latest traffic-growth plans and new USD/SGD estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Our Target Price climbs to SGD9.80, still at FY20E P/BV of 0.82x, 1SD below its 10-year mean.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: SIA’s share price has declined by 13% in the last quarter. As we believe this has priced in its near-term challenges, upgrade to HOLD.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Overall traffic (passenger + cargo) in 2QFY19 grew 2.9% y-o-y. Load factor went up by 1.7% y-o-y to 73.3%. This was the group’s highest load factor since 2010.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Changi Airport has slapped a SGD13.30 or 39% increase in passenger tariffs beginning Jul 2018.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: We also notice that published ticket fares are on the low side and factor in an 8% yield decline for 2QFY19 (8% decline in 1QFY19).

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: The fuel market is exceptionally volatile due to the US-China trade war and US embargo on Iran. As SIA has hedged 47% of its FY19 requirements at USD65/bbl (Brent), it should be better positioned than the other airlines.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: SIA’s 2QFY19 will be saddled with big losses from its 20% associate, Virgin Australia (VAH AU, Not Rated), which reported a net loss of AUD603.5m in its 2H18 results. SIA’s share of losses could be SGD50-60m in 2QFY19 but we deem this non-core as the bulk is accounting in nature.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: We also believe we have adequately factored in its near-term risks.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Traffic growth healthy

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Passengers carried by the group grew 8.4% y-o-y to 9.1m in 2QFY19. This was above its long-term average of 5% growth (excluding its Tigerair acquisition), which suggests healthy passenger traffic growth.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Cargo growth was equally healthy at 2.9% y-o-y in 2QFY19.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Load factor

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Group passenger load factor soared by 3.1ppts y-o-y to 84.9% in 2QFY19. We think yields were dropped in order to promote loads.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Cargo load factor was slightly down by 0.5ppt y-o-y to 63.5%. The air cargo industry has been performing very well in the past 2.5 years, driven by growth in the electronics segment and Internet retail sales.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: SIA has been trading range-bound, close to 1SD below its P/BV mean, in the past two years. We believe 1SD below mean is an apt valuation, given that its short-term outlook is clouded by volatile fuel prices, higher Changi Airport charges and huge one-off losses from Virgin Australia.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: Using a one-year forward P/BV of 0.82x, we derive a Target Price of SGD9.80 after our earnings revisions.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY19 Challenges In The Price
arguments: SIA’s share price has declined by 13% in the last three months. As we believe this has priced in its near-term challenges, upgrade to HOLD from SELL.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot

arguments: Pertinent points from analyst briefing

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: Swing Factors

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: SIA’s 4QFY16 and FY16 results were way below ours and consensus expectations.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: Yields were much weaker and the cargo business continued to lose money?. However, to its credit, SIA has achieved credible unit cost reduction through efficiency gains.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: We lower our FY17-18 forecasts by -3.2% and -6.7%, respectively to incorporate its latest fuel hedges and lower yields, and introduce a FY19 forecast.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: Maintain HOLD with a 2.5% lower TP of SGD11.5 (from SGD11.8), pegged to an unchanged 1x FY17 P/BV, which is SIA’s historical mean.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: Central to SIA’s quandary are the three giant Middle Eastern carriers, which have made commanding inroads into the premium segment.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: Secondly, all the mainline Chinese carriers have splurged capacity on trans-Pacific flights and this has hurt SIA’s market share, as well as marginalize its cargo segment. These pressures are unlikely to abate anytime soon, in our view.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: The bright sparks were Silkair and Scoot, which delivered strong YoY growth. Tigerair also breakeven in FY16.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: We forecast overall yields (passenger + cargo) to erode by a further 3.7% in FY17 as the long-haul sector continues to face stiff competition. However, we forecast unit cost to decline by 4.2% YoY in FY17 as SIA enjoys the benefit of the lower fuel price as its expensive fuel hedges expire.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: SIA will also derive some cost savings on the planned removal of two older Boeing B747-4F, one Boeing B777-3 and four Airbus A330-3, and replace them with ultra-modern and efficient new aircraft models.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: SIA announced a DPS of SGD0.35 (+106% YoY), bringing the full-year total to SGD0.45 (+105% YoY).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments: Its 65% payout ratio is among the highest in the industry and the current dividend yield of 4.0% will appeal to certain investors and provide downside support to the share price.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
Management expects an extremely challenging operating environment for the
year.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
The Middle Eastern and also Chinese carriers are growing at a fast pace and
hurting the yields on the premium segment.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
The budget segment is more resilient
and is growing strongly.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
The core growth markets for SIA are India and China. Management is optimistic
regarding buoyant demand in these two countries, driven by a strong domestic
economy, a resurgence of the middle income class population, and a rapidly
globalizing economy.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
We agree with management’s views that India and China
are indeed the new ‘big market’ for a long time to come.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
There will be a net addition of ten aircraft in FY17, with the addition of 17
aircraft and the removal of seven older aircraft from the fleet. This includes the
decommissioning of two freighter aircraft, its first reduction since 2011.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
SIA will
induct the ultra-modern Airbus A350 and Boeing 787 aircraft models, whilst
removing the older Boeing 777-3, Airbus A330-3, and Boeing 747-4F. This fleet
rejuvenation should help reduce unit cost and possibly appeal to more
customers.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
We are positive with management’s action to rejuvenate its fleet, as SIA has the
oldest average fleet age of any state carrier in the ASEAN region. But we are
concerned with the high number of net fleet additions in FY17. For the past five
years, SIA has typically only grown its fleet by 3-5 aircraft p.a.. Therefore, we
think there is a high probability that SIA will return five leased Airbus A380
aircraft that are due to expire to the lessor in 2017.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
There were plenty of
questions regarding the A380 aircraft status, but management was adamant that
it has yet to reach such a decision.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
There has been wide speculation in the press that Tigerair and Scoot will be
merged soon, which management has not denied nor confirmed.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
We believe it
will eventually happen, and the real question is when? In our opinion, it would be
mutually beneficial longer-term, assuming they can streamline operations and
reduce the overlapping staff functions. Should the merger story occur, we think
it could potentially improve the sentiment on the counter.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
Yield is the most important earnings driver, but the trend
has been negative for the past three years.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot

Low fuel price is providing a significant cost reduction
and boost to the bottom line.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
Strong demand and supply scarcity in the region should
drive up loads and yields in the medium term.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
Tigerair acquisition is costly and the market is keen to
see how it extracts value to benefit the Group.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
An increase in the value of the SGD against destination
countries and the USD will have an adverse effect on
yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Always on the back foot
arguments:
Increased competitive pressure from the Middle Eastern
carriers and also from regional peers who have upgraded
their fleets and services.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: The SIA group may struggle to deliver earnings growth in FY17

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: SIA’s full-year FY16 core net profit came in 6% below expectations, implying a 4Q that underperformed 22%, mainly due to more-than-expected yield declines.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: The group increased its profits in FY16 vs. FY15, as lower oil prices more than offset yield declines, but the incremental fuel price drop will be smaller in FY17.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: Juxtapose that against accelerating yield declines, and the group may not deliver EPS growth this year, which is why we have cut FY17-18 core EPS by 29-34%.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: We think it is time to lock in SIA’s outperformance, hence we downgrade from Add to Hold; our target is lowered to S$12.42, still based on P/BV of 1.1x (avg since 2001).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: The SIA group grew its full-year core earnings by 61%, as the lagged effect of lower oil prices finally flowed down to the bottom line with the gradual expiry of expensive legacy fuel hedges.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: The passenger airlines businesses (mainline SIA, SilkAir, Scoot and Tigerair) all saw improved profits for that reason. SilkAir and Scoot also had the benefit of new 737 and 787 planes, respectively, which helped them to improve operating efficiencies.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: The 4Q yield declines accelerated across the board, and could extend into FY17.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: The continuing decline of mainline SIA’s monthly yields is of special concern, due to weakness in long-haul and premium travel demand.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: The cargo business was especially dire, with SIA Cargo delivering its largest loss in almost three years, due to weak demand and excess capacity, causing large yield declines.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: Scoot was the only airline within the group that did not see its yields decline, despite growing its capacity 41% yoy in 2HFY16. Instead, it reported its second consecutive quarterly profit in 4Q16, which was even higher than the immediately preceding 3Q, and surprisingly equalled that of SilkAir in just a few short years of its existence. This was achieved on the back of strong demand which lifted loads to 85% (the highest in the SIA group), the growing maturity of its route network, and its new and efficient 787s.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: SilkAir delivered much stronger earnings than the year before, with a modest yield drop that was more than offset by a larger unit cost decline. The latter was achieved on the back of the new 737 fleet, capacity expansion and lower oil prices.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: Once concern is that SilkAir’s 4Q16 yields fell at a faster pace of 8.2% yoy, vs. 3Q16’s 3.5% decline.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: The group’s all-in price of jet fuel fell US$33/bbl yoy in FY16 (to US$84), but we forecast it to drop ‘only’ US$13/bbl in FY17 (to US$71), inclusive of hedging losses. This is based on a spot price assumption of US$60 and SIA’s existing 31% hedge book at an average strike price of US$81. The smaller drop is of concern if yield declines accelerate.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: The cargo business could see larger losses in FY17, while mainline SIA’s profits could shrink slightly on yield pressures, offset by higher earnings at SilkAir and Scoot.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Hard for SIA to grow earnings in near term
arguments: The net result could be flattish group profits that may not inspire share price performance.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
