title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
arguments: Earlier last month, Virgin Australia (VAH) started its review of capital structure and as an initial step, it secured a new 12-month A$425m loan facility with its four major shareholders including Air New Zealand (Air NZ, 25.9%) and Singapore Airlines (SIA, 23.1%).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
arguments: However, Air NZ announced late last month that it is now considering partial or full exit from its investment in VAH, currently valued at ~A$338m (7 Apr close).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
arguments: SIA also subsequently stated that it is committed to providing its proportion of the shareholder loan to VAH.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
arguments: Over the past five years, VAH has transformed from being a pure low-cost carrier to become a more diversified carrier, competing in the same space as the established full service carrier, Qantas, which is also a fierce rival of SIA on inbound and outbound routes from Australia and New Zealand.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
arguments: More recently, SIA increased its stake in VAH from 22.9% to 23.1% through a series of equity swaps, done at a premium to the open market price. While the increase in stake is only 0.2%, we believe the key inference one should draw from these transactions is SIA showing its commitment in its interest in VAH.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
arguments: Apart from Europe, Australasia is another key market of SIA, and a majority stake in VAH may help SIA compete more effectively with the existing dominant player – Qantas. Therefore, we do not rule out the possibility of SIA buying over Air NZ’s stake in VAH, but such action will trigger a takeover bid (based on ASX rules).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
arguments: In our view, gaining control of VAH could lift SIA’s competitiveness in the Australasia market with a larger presence and network synergy with the main group.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
arguments: All said, with nothing confirmed, such possibility remains a speculative view but investors may want to monitor for further corporate actions ahead.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
arguments: In our view, the near-term focus for SIA continues to hinge on earnings recovery resulting from cheap jet fuel and a beneficial hedging position for at least FY17.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Committed to interest in Virgin Australia
arguments: Keeping our forecasts unchanged for now, we reiterate BUY on SIA with the same FV of S$12.50.

arguments: January’s traffic growth was led by a whopping 56% yoy rise in visitor arrivals from China. Visitors from Indonesia, the second largest segment, rose 9% yoy. This could be due to a low base in the aftermath of the Indonesia AirAsia QZ8501 crash in Dec 14. However, this is not the case for Chinese visitors which saw double-digit growth for 10 consecutive months.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Strong Growth In Changi Airport Bodes Well For SATS, SIA And SIA Engineering In 4QFY16
arguments: Going forward, we expect Changi Airport’s pax throughput to remain buoyant as low air fares and increased airline capacity to regional destinations such as Malaysia, Thailand and Australia, lead to spillover tourist arrivals as well as transit traffic.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Strong Growth In Changi Airport Bodes Well For SATS, SIA And SIA Engineering In 4QFY16

arguments: With 81% and 79% market share of Changi Airport’s pax throughput and flight movements in 3QFY16 respectively, SATS will be a direct beneficiary of the surge in both pax throughput and flight movements. Both SATS’ unit meals and unit services have high correlations of 78% and 72% to the number of pax handled and flights handled at Changi respectively.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Strong Growth In Changi Airport Bodes Well For SATS, SIA And SIA Engineering In 4QFY16
arguments: Assuming Changi airport’s pax throughput rises 9% in 1Q16, SATS unit services could rise 11-14% in 4QFY16, which could in turn boost gateway services revenue by 6-7%. This is higher than our implied estimate of a 3% growth in gateway services.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Strong Growth In Changi Airport Bodes Well For SATS, SIA And SIA Engineering In 4QFY16
arguments: Earnings could thus surprise to the upside. We also believe the market has yet to factor in such an eventuality.

arguments: SIA, Silk Air and Scoot’s pax carriage rose 5.6%, 10.8% and 48.1% yoy respectively in 2M16.

arguments: Higher pax and aircraft movements.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Collaboration and partnerships the way forward?
arguments: In view of intensifying competition from expanding Gulf carriers (e.g. Emirates and Qatar Airways), we highlighted in our previous reports that forming more collaboration and partnerships may be one of Singapore Airlines’ (SIA) focus going forward.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Collaboration and partnerships the way forward?
arguments: Recently, SIA and Tourism Malaysia entered into a two-year partnership to increase tourist flow into Malaysia, with a focus on 14 major inbound markets that include U.K., Russia, U.S., India, and China, by leveraging on SIA and SilkAir’s existing network.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Collaboration and partnerships the way forward?
arguments: And just yesterday, SIA and SilkAir signed a codeshare agreement with Air China mainly on routes between Singapore, Beijing and Chengdu. Given SIA’s positioning in the market, we think this codeshare agreement may potentially dilute SIA’s parent airline branding and image on its Beijing flights but we also do not rule out the possibility of this agreement opening up further opportunities between the two airlines.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Collaboration and partnerships the way forward?
arguments: All said, we still expect the cheap jet fuel to drive its earnings recovery in FY17, as the expensive hedges unwind progressively ahead.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Collaboration and partnerships the way forward?
arguments: Maintain BUY with an unchanged FV of S$12.50.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: Sector picks and implications

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: We view the 2016 Budget as one that is focused on long-term transformation needs of Singapore, spiced up with targeted aids for struggling sectors/workers.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: Budget deficit of 1.2% for 2015. 2016 spending will increase by 7%, supported by higher operating revenues (one-off factors) and net investment returns.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments:
Main investment implications: 

 likely slower bank NPLs from SMEs and stretched households; and 
 no reprieve for property stocks from unwind of measures.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: likely slower bank NPLs from SMEs and stretched households; and

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: no reprieve for property stocks from unwind of measures.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: The past two Budgets evolved from one with a heavy social safety net slant, to one that was focused on the long-term repositioning needs of the country.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: 2016 Budget did not represent a major directional change to the long-term aim, but it did add incremental measures to help distressed segments of industries and workers.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: raise corporate tax rebates for SMEs;

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: raise incentives (to companies) for retaining older workers;

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: introduce new working capital loans to SMEs (with government risk-share);

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: support heartland businesses; and

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: defer foreign worker levy increases for the offshore and marine sector.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: Anti-speculation property measures were, however, not removed.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: helping enterprises transform to new business models;

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: making use of new technologies; and 3) assisting SMEs to internationalise.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: The initiatives aim to foster some economies of scale advantages in capital investments. The Finance Minister noted that industry level modernisation works best, if companies work in a group. An example was the use of robotics in manufacturing, where a single company might not be able to roll out initiatives alone. The Budget will put aside funds to set up the Singapore Innovation Center to facilitate innovation.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: There is also a new trade finance platform to cut costs and improve information share. The centralised platform provides an environment for development of new apps (useful for multiple companies), which will improve productivity for multiple companies.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments:
Outside of industry support measures, measures to support workers include: 

more SkillsFuture initiatives to help people acquire new skills to match the demand of new sectors/deepen skills in focused sectors; 
expansion of wage support scheme to encourage firms to hire Singaporeans; and 
new approaches to job matching.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: more SkillsFuture initiatives to help people acquire new skills to match the demand of new sectors/deepen skills in focused sectors;

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: expansion of wage support scheme to encourage firms to hire Singaporeans; and

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: new approaches to job matching.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments:
2016 Budget is one with calibrated measures for particular segments of industries and the workforce. Implications for the stock market include: 

some shield in banking NPLs (SMEs and stretched households); 
no unwind of property measures ; and 
mild relief for offshore and marine.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: some shield in banking NPLs (SMEs and stretched households);

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: no unwind of property measures ; and

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: mild relief for offshore and marine.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: Our top picks remain OCBC, SIA and THBEV.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: Banks are cheap and asset quality concerns are overblown, in our view. OCBC is our top pick for its joint-lowest NPL ratio, despite booking oil and gas NPLs in 3Q. OCBC also has the highest provision coverage for unsecured NPLs.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: SIA is a late beneficiary of low oil price. In addition to low er fuel costs, other initiatives such as the launch of premium economy and fuel-efficient new planes will contribute to positive earnings surprise potential.

title: Singapore Strategy  - Calibrated Budget keeps focus on long term
arguments: Thai Beverage delivered strong execution for beer in 4Q and is creating a second division to generate cash flow to fund its fierce fight in the non-alcoholic segment and M&As to expand earnings contribution from outside of Thailand

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Solid operating statistics a pleasant surprise

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Sacrificing yields for loads

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Raise FV to S$12.50 on higher valuation peg

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Strong operating results

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Fuel savings to offset low yields

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Upgrade to BUY

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Singapore Airlines’ (SIA) operating results for the first two months (i.e. Jan & Feb 16) of 4QFY16 came in strong with overall passenger traffic YoY growth (Jan: +6.8%, Feb: +8.4%) outpacing capacity growth (Jan: +2.0%, Feb: +5.4%).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Despite mixed global economic data, traffic for its parent airline grew 3.8% and 5.1% YoY, which led to a 3.7ppt and 2.2ppt improvement in passenger load factors (PLF) in Jan 16 and Feb 16, respectively.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: The improvements in PLF were broad-based across all regions supported by promotional activities, led by East Asia (+6.5ppt) in Jan 16 and Europe (+4.3ppt) in Feb 16.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Traffic growth were also strong for both SilkAir (Jan: +17.5%, Feb: +11.6%) and Scoot (Jan: +46.0%, Feb: +48.2%), supported by East Asia and Pacific growth for the former and addition of new destination to Guangzhou in mid-Jan 16 for the latter.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Unsurprisingly, SIA Cargo continued to register weak cargo loads on persistent industry overcapacity.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: While operating results were encouraging, we believe SIA may be sacrificing yields to ensure stable passenger loads.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Pricing competition is likely to persist as Gulf carriers continue to expand into SIA’s key routes to Europe and the low oil price environment may exacerbate such competition since it increases the ability of airlines to price down tickets.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Being one of the key beneficiaries of cheap jet fuel, SIA is also likely able to compete on pricing through promotional activities to maintain its market share, at least on its key Europe routes. That said, we expect cheap jet fuel to more than offset the low yields in FY17.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: In addition, we expect profitability on both SilkAir and Scoot to improve further, and potentially even more if interlining traffic between Scoot and Tigerair can be captured effectively.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Keeping our forecasts unchanged for now, we raise our target peg from 1.0x to 1.1x FY17F P/B (-0.25SD 10-year mean), as we expect the more expensive hedges to progressively unwind and provide a lift to earnings in FY17.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Cheap jet fuel to lift FY17 earnings
arguments: Consequently, our FV increases from S$11.70 to S$12.50 and we upgrade SIA from HOLD to BUY.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: WHAT’S NEW

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: STOCK IMPACT

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: EARNINGS REVISION/RISK

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: VALUATION/RECOMMENDATION

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: SHARE PRICE CATALYST

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: In an environment of weak jobs growth and soft global economy outlook, SIA’s strong traffic numbers highlight a willingness to travel for both the full-service and low-cost segments.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: This, along with stronger loads, more fuel-efficient aircraft, as well as low fuel prices, should lower the risk profile of the group.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: Maintain BUY. Target price: S$13.90.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: SIA’s pax load factor surged by 2.2ppt in Feb as traffic growth (+5%yoy) outpaced capacity growth.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: There was broad-based improvement in load factor across all regions, with Europe showing the biggest improvement (+4.3ppt). This is especially encouraging, given the Europe sector’s significance to SIA due to its relatively higher premium traffic.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: Overall, SIA’s pax loads averaged 78.9% in Jan-Feb 16, significantly higher than the previous year (75.8%).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: SilkAir’s 11.6% pax traffic growth in February was led by demand out of East Asia, Pacific and West Asia regions.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: Meanwhile Scoot’s traffic grew by a whopping 48% yoy in Feb 16, but capacity expanded at a faster rate as the tenth B787 Dreamliner entered the fleet in Jan.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: SIA’s cargo loads fell 4.3ppt in February on the back of a decline in cargo traffic (-2.3% yoy), exacerbated by capacity expansion. SIA had earlier warned on weakness in cargo due to overcapacity in the region and soft demand.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: We reckon that cargo yields could have been adversely affected. There is some downside risk to our cargo yield estimates as we have factored in a 8.6% decline in cargo yields vs a 10.3% decline as at 9MFY16.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: SIA’s continued improvement in pax load factors and subsidiaries SilkAir and Scoot’s strong traffic growth underscore SIA’s improving operational strength. This, along with lower fuel cost as well as more efficient aircraft, is expected to lead to increased profitability in 4Q.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: Ytd, SIA has achieved pax loads of 79.8%, higher than our assumption of 79.5% for FY16. There is upside risk to our earnings estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: SIA is gradually rolling out greater premium economy seating and we reckon that it is well received by the marketplace.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: In addition, loads to Europe remain strong and SIA’s CEO has been on record as stating that there is no weakness seen in business traffic. Thus, pax yields are likely to be resilient in 4QFY16. However, we are cognisant of the risk to business traffic and yields, given recent downsizing in the financial sector.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: No change to our earnings estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: We continue to value SIA at 1.0x FY17F book value. We expect SIA’s FY17 earnings to improve, driven by increased profitability of SilkAir and Scoot, more efficient aircraft, as well as low fuel prices as fuel hedges unwind.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: We also like SIA for its expected ROE (3Y SIA ex-SIAEC avg: 8.8%) above cost of equity (7%), and stabilising yields. Maintain BUY with a target price of S$13.90.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Ytd Pax Load Factor Rises 3ppt, While Scoot’s Traffic Grows A Whopping 47% In 2M16
arguments: Higher-than-expected pax yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - To take full ownership of Tigerair
arguments: Singapore Airlines’ (SIA) general offer for Tigerair will close today and Tigerair is set to become a wholly owned subsidiary of SIA since the compulsory acquisition threshold was achieved during the offer period.

title: Singapore Airlines  - To take full ownership of Tigerair
arguments: Shareholders who did not respond to the offer will receive a letter from SIA on the compulsory acquisition of their shares in due course.

title: Singapore Airlines  - To take full ownership of Tigerair
arguments: Separately, SIA has also taken delivery of its first Airbus A350-900, which arrived in Singapore yesterday morning and is the first of the 67 A350 aircraft on firm order. Even though the new A350s will allow SIA to serve more long-haul destinations with improved fuel efficiency, we believe the yields on SIA’s key routes to Europe are still under pressure due to intensifying competition from the Gulf carriers (e.g. Emirates and Qatar Airways).

title: Singapore Airlines  - To take full ownership of Tigerair
arguments: While we remain cautiously optimistic on the potential significant savings from cheap jet fuel, we think SIA’s hedging policy may continue to reduce such savings on significant hedging losses. Therefore, we prefer to get clarity over its FY17 hedging positions before reviewing our assumptions again.

title: Singapore Airlines  - To take full ownership of Tigerair
arguments: Maintain HOLD with an unchanged FV of S$11.70.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Banks and telco

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Property & REITs

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Conglomerates, industrials, transport

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Conviction ideas

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Reflecting subdued expectations, 4Q15 beat-to-miss ratio was 1.7x i.e. positive. But our FSSTI EPS was cut 3.2%, as the quantum of negative surprises was big.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: 4Q catchphrase is “impairment”, appearing repeatedly in industrials and property.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Environment is still tough but the recent selldown has thrown up bargains. We like banks, property and REITs. Super and Sarine are non-Index names we highlight.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Asset quality concerns dominated the 4Q discussions for banks, as oil & gas names faced greater cash flow strain. DBS allayed concerns stating its oil & gas loans were extended at 50% loan-to-value ratio. UOB raised its specific allowance guidance to 35-40bp. We are Overweight on banks as current valuations of below 1x FY16 P/BV reflect overblown asset quality concerns. It would take 200bp provisioning to wipe out earnings in a year and impair book values. We like OCBC the most.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: saw associates’ contribution strengthen in 4Q, while Starhub was hit by higher costs. We are Neutral on telcos as valuations are not cheap versus other sectors.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Across the REITs, the healthcare and overseas office/retail segments did better in 4Q, while hospitality and industrial showed increasing signs of a slowdown. Our top picks for REIT previously were CMT, MAGIC, CCT. We now replace CMT with KDCREIT as CMT has done very well in FY15.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: “Impairment” was the buzzword for developers. Most had yoy earnings decline in 4Q due to the lack of development profits to book. UOL replaces CAPL among our top picks (previously CIT, CAPL), given its higher development sales in recent years and likely resilient earnings. Wing Tai remains least preferred due to future QC issues.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Impairments popped up for both yards in 4Q, as they took hits for Sete Brasil and other rigs. The yards’ book values are shrinking and net gearing (0.5-0.8x) is rising. Names like Ezion are making provisions for receivables. The sector’s key focus is to survive this period. We prefer STE that has other divisions pulling their weight.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: One of the few bright lights of 4Q was SIA. The benefits of lower fuel costs are showing. Scoot and SilkAir are doing well. SIA remains our top pick in transport.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: GENS showed signs of recovery, as its gaming volumes and bad debt stabilised and 4Q earnings missed purely due to poor win rates. Luck factors tend to mean-revert.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: IHH remains a preferred pick, as rising revenue intensity offset slower volumes in 4Q.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Consumer is showing signs of turnaround, with Super’s 4Q results as a highlight. Our top pick, Thai Beverage, did well in 4Q due to huge uptick in domestic beer sales.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Our large-cap picks are CIT, OCBC, IHH, SIA, THBEV, UOL; OCBC, SIA and UOL replace DBS, SPOST and CAPL.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Our small-cap conviction names are GLL, HOBEE, IP, MAGIC, SARINE, SUPER and VMS. New additions are SARINE and SUPER.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Banks are cheap and asset quality concerns are overblown, in our view. OCBC is our top pick for its joint-lowest NPL ratios, despite booking oil and gas NPLs in 3Q.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: OCBC also has the highest provision coverage to unsecured NPLs.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: SIA is a late beneficiary of low oil price. In addition to lower fuel costs, other initiatives such as the launching of premium economy and fuel-efficient new planes will contribute to positive earnings surprise potential.

title: Singapore Strategy  - 4Q catchphrase ~ impairment
arguments: Thai Beverage delivered strong execution for beer in 4Q and is creating a second division to generate cash flow to fund its fierce fight in the non-alcoholic segment and M&As to expand earnings contribution from outside of Thailand.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments: Yields still weakening

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments: Partnerships and higher-yielding products the way forward

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments: Increase FV; maintain HOLD

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
Singapore Airlines’ (SIA) 3QFY16 reported PATMI improved 35.7% YoY
                                              to S$275.6m, on the back of higher operating profit, driven mainly by
                                              improvements from parent airline, SilkAir and Scoot, which turned in its
                                              first ever operating profit since its launch in 2012.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
Stripping out disposal gains of S$53.3m arising mainly from
                                              SilkAir’s sale and leaseback of four 737-800s, 3QFY16 PATMI YoY
                                              growth is 7.9%.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
3QFY16 group revenue fell 3.9%, or S$158m, to S$3.94b due to a 4.6% drop
                                              in passenger yield and a 13.5% decline in cargo yield; partially offset by
                                              higher carriage.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
3QFY16 total operating expenses declined 7.6% YoY to S$3.65b, largely
                                              due to lower net fuel costs (-23.7%), as average jet fuel price dropped by
                                              a material 41.1%. However, fuel savings were partially offset by
                                              strengthening of USD against SGD, hedging losses, higher tax expense,
                                              impairment of aircraft and weaker results of associated companies.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
Competition will intensify as Gulf carriers, mainly Emirates and Qatar
                                              Airways, are able to offer lower fares for a prolonged-period, especially
                                              on the Asia-Europe routes.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
We believe this will result in a persistent low-yield environment for
                                              the airline industry. However, over the longer term, we believe
                                              SIA’s efforts in multiple fronts will certainly help mitigate and
                                              could even overcome such competition by: 
                                              
 forming strategic partnerships with other airlines (e.g. the most
                                                  recent one was with Lufthansa) to counter competition on its key
                                                  routes; 
 offering higher-yielding products such as premium economy class to
                                                  counter declining yields; 
 buying fuel efficient A350s for parent airline and B787s for Scoot
                                                  to lower its unit costs to improve operating margins; and lastly 
                                                
 unlocking synergies to capture interlining traffic between Scoot
                                                  and Tigerair (i.e. replicating synergy between parent airline and
                                                  SilkAir).

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
offering higher-yielding products such as premium economy class to
                                                  counter declining yields;

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
buying fuel efficient A350s for parent airline and B787s for Scoot
                                                  to lower its unit costs to improve operating margins; and lastly

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
unlocking synergies to capture interlining traffic between Scoot
                                                  and Tigerair (i.e. replicating synergy between parent airline and
                                                  SilkAir).

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
Before these efforts start to bear fruits, we expect pressures on yields
                                              to weigh on SIA’s performance in the near term. However, we expect
                                              cheaper jet fuel to help boost SIA’s bottom-line and raise our FY17F
                                              PATMI by 24.2%.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 3QFY16 above expectations
arguments:
Rolling forward our valuation to 1.0x FY17 P/B, our 12-month FV
                                                increases from S$11.45 to S$11.70. Maintain HOLD.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: WHAT’S NEW

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: STOCK IMPACT

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: EARNINGS REVISION/RISK

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: VALUATION/RECOMMENDATION

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: SHARE PRICE CATALYST

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: We met with SIA’s management. SIA’s strong 3QFY16 results and qoq improvement in pax yields underscore the impact of lower fuel hedges and the resilience of front-end yields.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: Forward bookings were also higher as compared with a year ago.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: Going forward, we expect SIA’s earnings to improve as fuel hedges unwind, combined with improved profitability of SilkAir and Scoot, as well as stabilising yields.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: We trim our target price slightly to S$13.90 as we assume lower cargo yields. Maintain BUY.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: The decline in revenue on the back of lower yields was less than the decline in opex (mainly fuel cost) and this led to the incremental operating margin. A weaker Singapore dollar however led to net S$65m negative impact on net profit.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments:
Going into FY17, earnings are likely to improve further as: 

 fuel hedges unwind, 
 yields stabilise as more premium economy seats are launched, and 
 SilkAir and Scoot’s profitability improves with more fuel efficient aircraft.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: fuel hedges unwind,

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: yields stabilise as more premium economy seats are launched, and

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: SilkAir and Scoot’s profitability improves with more fuel efficient aircraft.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: Despite weakness in the oil and gas sector and job attritions in the financial sector, SIA’s corporate travel market held its own. In addition, SIA indicated that demand for premium economy seats were especially strong on London, Sydney and Auckland routes with loads of 80% and higher, but cautioned that it was weak on Chinese and Indian routes.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: SIA also indicated that forward bookings were higher as compared with a year ago, for both business and economy class, but was stronger for back end. This holds scope for stable yields in 4QFY16. Forward bookings, as at 3QFY16, rose 6.6% yoy.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: SIA indicated Scoot’s capacity is likely to rise by 20-30% over the next few years and envisions strong demand and improved operating efficiency on new aircraft.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: We believe that Scoot will become increasingly material to SIA group’s earnings.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: On the cargo front, SIA lamented that yields were exceptionally weak across most sectors due to overcapacity in the region.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: We have thus lowered our cargo yield assumptions for FY16 and FY17 by 2% and 3% respectively.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: SIA highlighted that together with its codeshare partners, it connects to greater destinations and has higher frequencies than Emirates and its partners.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: Also, SIA’s enhanced codeshare partnership with Lufthansa has not yet secured regulatory approval but following which, both carriers will operate revenue sharing on Singapore - Zurich, Singapore - Dusseldorf, Singapore - Munich and Singapore - Frankfurt. SIA will then be able to tap on to corporate travel in the region and provide further connection to South West Pacific.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: There is also the potential for yield accretion as Lufthansa’s pax yield is about 27% higher than that of SIA.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: We believe that the street will raise earnings estimates, factoring in lower fuel hedging losses as well as improvements at Scoot.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: as we exclude the reversal of cargo antitrust fines and assume lower cargo yields, but raise our pax yield assumptions. SIA has guided that the reversal of cargo fines may take longer than expected. We also reduce our FY17 net profit estimates by 5%, as we lower our cargo yield estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: We continue to value SIA at 1.0x FY17 book value. We have assumed a FY16 final dividend of 38 S cents (65% payout ratio, ex-SIAEC’s divestment gains), as SIA indicated that SIAEC’s restructuring of JVs may not be completed in 4QFY16.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: We still like SIA for the expected fuel cost savings as fuel hedges unwind, the increasing potential for stable yields as well as the expected improvement in SilkAir and Scoot’s profitability.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: Maintain BUY with a target price of S$13.90.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Resilient Front-end Yields And Optimistic On SilkAir And Scoot
arguments: Higher-than-expected pax and cargo yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: Investors rather apathetic towards SIA, but…

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: Don’t forget the beneficial structural changes coming up

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: SIA delivered above-expectation 3Q16 results, with YTD numbers requiring us to raise our FY16 core EPS forecast by 18.5% on lower-than-expected yield declines.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: SIA, SilkAir, Tigerair and Scoot all benefitted lower fuel prices and higher loads which more than offset yield pressures, resulting in higher yoy profitability.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: Only SIA Cargo did worse than last year, due to very significant yield pressures.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: Maintain Add with a higher target price (S$13.00), still based on P/BV of 1.1x (avg since 2001). Catalysts include lower fuel prices, and strong execution by SilkAir and Scoot.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: SIA’s 2Q16 had disappointed our expectations, but after lowering our numbers, SIA delivered 3Q results that surprised us on the upside, so we expect consensus numbers to be upgraded.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: While we had reflected lower fuel prices into our FY16 projections, we also factored in a low level of yields that the group passenger airlines managed to beat, i.e. we may have been too conservative in our assumption of accelerating yield declines.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: Lower jet fuel prices also started to have a larger beneficial impact to net earnings.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: All the group pax airlines delivered much stronger yoy profits, with Scoot reporting its maiden profit.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: Yields dropped across the board, due to aggressive competition and the weak economic cycle affecting SIA mainline, and due to strong capacity growth at SilkAir and Scoot that required price stimulus.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: But unit costs dropped even more, due to lower fuel prices and the delivery of fuel-efficient 738/787 planes, and loads were generally higher also.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: Only SIA Cargo reported lower earnings, but at least it was profitable too.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: We met investors in the region last month, who were largely apathetic towards SIA.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: While the cheap oil story is known, investors were concerned about the degree of yield pressure that SIA mainline would face as a result of the weak global economies, and from rising competition with the Gulf carriers to Europe and with North Asian carriers to the US.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: Only investors who were mandated to track the FSSTI rejoiced at SIA’s continuing outperformance against the index.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: SIA acknowledged the tough realities, guiding for continuing “pressure on loads and yields”.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: The poor oil industry outlook and investment bank retrenchments could impact business class travel demand in the immediate future.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: At the same time, SIA’s average cost of fuel hedges are falling quickly, as SIA mainly hedges jet fuel over a horizon of not more than 12 months.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: In the end, it is all about the tug-of-war between yields and costs, and SIA’s 3Q results suggest that cost savings are beginning to gain the upper hand.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: SIA’s visionary strategy of growing SilkAir and Scoot and revitalising their fleet with new aircraft will likely yield dividends for years to come.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: The same applies to the growing portfolio of partnerships with other airlines.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Congratulations Scoot, you made it!
arguments: SIA mainline also introduced premium economy from August, is refreshing its suite of products, while the fuel-efficient A350s will be delivered soon. Investors can rest assured that SIA is staying ahead of the game.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 3QFY16 Results Preview ~ Rise In Headline Profits, Even With Fuel Hedging Losses

arguments: In 2QFY16, SIA guided that they have hedged 50.7% of their fuel requirements at US$93/bbl for 2HFY16. The differential between that and the into-plane fuel cost is likely to result in about S$350m in hedging losses.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 3QFY16 Results Preview ~ Rise In Headline Profits, Even With Fuel Hedging Losses
arguments: Going forward, we expect SIA’s fuel hedges to show sequential declines, which in turn will lower fuel hedging losses.

arguments: SIA’s hedge levels for the upcoming periods, along with the extent of pax yield decline, would have a significant bearing on future profitability. Meanwhile, we would also be looking out for the quantum of proceeds from aircraft disposal, which would boost cash flow and help offset capex commitments.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: Pax load factors improved across parent SIA and all subsidiaries in December, which is positive.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: We are encouraged by SIA’s and Scoot’s sustained high loads which, along with lower fuel costs, should lead to higher profitability for 3QFY16.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: Going forward, we believe that the sharp decline in fuel costs, combined with Scoot’s improved operational performance, should drive FY17’s earnings growth.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: Maintain BUY. Target price S$14.00.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: In December, SIA recorded pax load factor improvement of 0.3ppt. The strongest load factor improvement was in the West Asia and Africa regions. This was partially offset by a decline in loads to Europe, which SIA attributed to softer passenger demand, particularly France.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: We reckon this is likely due to the terrorist attacks in France. SIA also indicated that this is a “short-term dip”, suggesting signs of recovery in demand to Europe.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: Overall, 3Q’s strong loads are encouraging and suggest that SIA’s efforts to improve operations to boost utilisation are bearing fruit.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: The improvement was mainly due to strong demand during the quarter. Also, Scoot’s traffic grew by 22% ytd, resulting in a 2.6ppt load factor improvement even with rapid capacity expansion.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: Meanwhile, SilkAir’s pax loads rose 0.1ppt in December, but registered a 0.6ppt decline in 3QFY16 loads due to weaker loads in October.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: This comes despite SIA’s “cautious” cargo traffic outlook. SIA indicated this was due to additional ad-hoc charters and cargo loads were generally weak except in the Southwest Pacific region.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: We note that SIA’s 3QFY16 cargo loads were stronger than 2QFY16’s 60.3%.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: We expect 3QFY16’s substantial 1.7ppt load factor improvement to 80.0% to boost 3Q’s earnings.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: In 3QFY15, parent airline SIA recorded S$87m in operating profit on pax loads of 78.3% and pax yields of 11.5 S cents.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: We have assumed an 8% yoy decline in 2HFY16 pax yields (2QFY16: -4.6% yoy). Every 0.1 S cent rise in pax yield is expected to raise 2HFY16 and FY17 net profit by about S$46m and S$92.5m respectively.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: Coupled with lower fuel costs, this should lead to improved profitability for SIA.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: In 2QFY16, Scoot reported an operating loss of S$2m on load factor of 84.5%. Comparatively, Scoot delivered pax load factors of 86.0% in 3QFY16. Furthermore, Scoot’s pax yields have been relatively firm and in fact improved by 1.9% in 1HFY16. Thus, Scoot is likely to swing to profitability in 3QFY16 on higher loads, as well as cost savings from fuel and its fleet replacement programme.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: No change to our earnings estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments: We continue to value SIA at 1.0x FY17F SIA ex-SIAEC book value. We expect SIA’s earnings to be boosted by lower fuel costs and about a S$950m reduction in fuel hedging losses in FY17, leading to record FY17 net profits of S$1.5b, the highest in eight years. Every US$10/bbl decline in fuel cost is expected to lead to a S$517m rise in net profits.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Improved Pax Loads Across Parent SIA And All Subsidiaries
arguments:
We believe that P/B valuations should rise to at least 1x, given: 

 expected SIA ex-SIAEC’s FY17 ROE of 11% above its cost of equity, 
 potentially stabilising yields, and 
 the fact that the stock traded at 1.2x P/B in 2010 when earnings breached S$1b.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: The 2-year forward Brent continues to decline across the curve, ranging from US$32/bbl to US$44/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Meanwhile, Brent and jet fuel swaps amount to just US$13.5/bbl, suggesting that jet fuel hedging cost would amount to US$45/bbl to US$58/bbl. Under such an environment, we believe SIA should deserve to trade at a higher P/B as profits are likely to rise.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Every US$10/bbl decline in fuel cost will add S$570m to its PBT and S$513m to net profit. This translates into a 3.9% improvement in ROE.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: We have also assumed SIA would have hedged 40% of its fuel requirements for FY17 at US$70/bbl (previously US$76/bbl). This effectively lowers our FY17 fuel cost estimate by 14%.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: We believe that much of the decline in pax yields in the past four quarters was a response to the steep increase in fuel price volatility and aggressive price discounting by competitors.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: In 2016, we believe ticket prices will be more stable as there is no sign of demand destruction for leisure travel.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: For FY16 and FY17, we have assumed a 6% and 1.7% decline in pax yields to 10.5 and 10.35 S cents respectively. Comparatively, in 2009 when Brent reached a low of US$42/bbl, pax yields subsequently declined to 9.8 S cents in 2QFY10 but averaged 10.4 S cents for the year.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Every 0.1 S cent decline in pax yield from our base assumption for 2HFY16 will lower SIA’s 2HFY16 net profit by 5%.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: Every 0.1 S cent decline in pax yield from our base assumption for FY17 will lower SIA’s FY17 net profit by 6%.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: SIA’s share price performance has been relatively resilient and outperformed the FSSTI by 11% in 2015 and 4.7% ytd. We note that in 2010, SIA ex-SIAEC traded at up to 1.2x book when profit breached S$1b. As such, we believe its P/B valuation could rise to at least 1x in FY17.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: SIA is expected to post higher fuel hedging losses in 2HFY16 vs 1HFY16 due to lower fuel prices. However, we project fuel hedging losses to fall sharply in FY17. We have assumed an average of US$70/bbl in fuel hedges and 40% of fuel requirements hedged for FY17. This should lead to about S$950m decline in fuel hedging losses in FY17.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments:
Our FY17 net profit estimate is 76% above consensus. The difference could be due to consensus: 

 has yet to adjust for fuel cost estimates, or 
 is factoring in a steep decline in yields.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments: ... as we lower our FY17 into-plane fuel price assumption from US$66/bbl to US$58/bbl. We also raise our FY16 net profit estimate by 11% on a lower fuel cost assumption of US$61/bbl from US$66/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Fuel Shock? SIA Is The Best Proxy Play; Upgrade To BUY
arguments:
We have ascribed a higher P/B multiple of 1.0x to SIA ex-SIAEC’s FY17 book, given: 

 the sharp decline in fuel prices, 
 potentially stabilising yields, 
 P/B valuation could rise to at least 1x, given SIA ex-SIAEC traded at 1.2x book in 2010 when earnings breached S$1b, and 
 ROE ex-SIAEC of 11% in FY17, well above SIA’s cost of equity of 7%.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: In 2015, Tigerair and SATS were outperformers, recording total returns of 55% and 31% respectively.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: In 2016, we expect SATS to generate 17% returns (net of dividend).

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: SATS remains our top pick within the Singapore aviation space and we expect the stock to generate 17% returns (net of dividend) for 2016. Catalysts are improved earnings from subsidiary TFK, cost savings as well as incentives from Changi Airport.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: We also favour SIA on expectations of lower fuel hedging losses and stable yields.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: SIA is expected to generate 13% returns for 2016 (inclusive of dividend). We would be buyers of SIA near S$10.80.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: Meanwhile, SIAEC remains the top sell within the sector. While its stock price is supported by a stock buyback, we expect the stock to underperform.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: Visitor arrivals to Japan in October and November rose 44% and 41% respectively, underpinned by a 100% and 75% rise in Chinese visitor arrivals.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: We expect the increased volume to flow through to a higher number of meals served and hence boost profits. In addition, the commencement of the Delta Airlines catering contract in September will lead to improved profitability.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: Earnings could receive a further boost when the new bullet train linking Tokyo to Hokkaido (Hokkaido Shinkansen Line) opens in Mar-16, boosting visitor arrivals at Narita Airport and Haneda Airport (TFK operates out of Narita and Haneda).

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: Wage pressures.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: SIA’s fuel hedges are expected to be added at progressively lower levels and every US$10/bbl difference in fuel price will lead to S$570m in cost savings. In addition, we believe that pressure on yields is likely to erode in the coming quarters as volatility on fuel prices have narrowed.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: In particular, the recent codeshare with Lufthansa should help to fend off competition from the Gulf carriers and enable SIA to tap into Lufthansa’s network to over 20 points in Europe via the Frankfurt, Munich and Zurich hubs. We believe this would boost loads to Europe. We also note that SIA’s pax load factors have risen for five consecutive months.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: .. as we factor in a S$136m reversal in European Commission antitrust fines for cargo price fixing (€75m). We have not assumed a payout of the reversal in fines. In addition, we have assumed that SIA would issue 12.5m new shares, following the exercise of share options by Tigerair shareholders.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: At current levels, SIA offers an attractive dividend yield of 4.7%. Our FY16 earnings estimate is the highest in the street, while our FY17 estimate is 29% above consensus.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: Greater-than-expected pax yield decline.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: Post the Rolls-Royce JV restructuring, SIAEC lost its status as the sole Centre of Excellence in Asia Pacific for the maintenance of Trent engines.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.
arguments: In addition, we expect SIAEC’s airframe maintenance revenue to decline further due to additional capacity from third-party maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) providers in the Philippines and Indonesia. For instance, GMF AeroAsia added a hangar in Jakarta in November, which can accommodate 15 narrowbody/7 widebody aircraft.

title: Singapore Aviation  - Positioning For Things To Come. Focus On SATS And SIA.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: We are impressed with SIA’s sequential improvement in pax load factor, which we believe is due to strategic codeshares.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: Unless yields deteriorate further, we believe 3Q’s earnings could surprise to the upside, especially with Scoot’s strong traffic growth.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: Going into FY17, we believe that SIA’s fuel hedges will drop sharply and lead to substantial profit growth.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: We roll forward our valuation to FY17’s equity base and value SIA at 0.85x book value vs 0.8x previously.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: Maintain HOLD. Target price S$12.00. Suggested entry level: S$10.80.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: Parent SIA’s pax load factor improved 3.1ppt in November, with stronger loads across all regions. The greatest load factor improvement was in long-haul routes, to West Asia, Africa, Southwest Pacific, Europe and the US. SIA attributed this to selective capacity adjustments and promotional activities.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: Pax loads for Oct 15 and Nov 15 averaged 79%, a 3ppt yoy increase.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: The strong traffic growth was likely due to the addition of new routes to Osaka, Kaohsiung and Hangzhou. Scoot also added a new route to Melbourne in November.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: The improving traffic growth and load factor could be a game changer for Scoot. In 2QFY16, Scoot reported an operating loss of S$2.0m on load factor of 84.5%. For Oct-Nov 15, Scoot registered a pax load factor of 84.3%. This, coupled with lower fuel cost and better operating efficiency on its nine B787 Dreamliners should swing Scoot to the black in 3QFY16 and potentially in 4Q as well.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: This does not come as a surprise as SIA has previously indicated they were “cautious” on cargo traffic outlook.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: Active capacity management and codeshares are likely to be the main reasons behind the improving load factor. Ytd, pax load factor has improved by 0.8ppt.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: We have previously assumed -0.2ppt decrease in load factor for FY16.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: Given the strength in ytd load factor, we raise our full-year load factor estimate to +0.6ppt by raising our traffic growth assumption. Every 1ppt improvement in load factor is expected to raise net profit by about S$50.0m, taking into account our base assumption of a 5.6% decline in yields for the period.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: In 2QFY16, SIA had hedged jet fuel at US$104/bbl and SIA had guided that 2HFY16’s jet fuel approximates US$93/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: We believe that SIA would have added to hedges for the period and 4QFY16’s hedges could be close to US$85/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: Given the trajectory of lower fuel prices, we believe that SIA’s fuel hedges for FY17 would be below US$80/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: We have assumed US$78/bbl for FY17. Every US$10/bbl decline in jet fuel costs will lead to an approximate S$570m increase in PBT for the group.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: We also raise our FY17 net profit estimate by 28% as we lower our jet fuel assumption for FY17 by US$4.5/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: We also raise our FY16 dividend estimate to 52 S cents per share (from 40 S cents), as we assume full payout of SIAEC’s divestment gains.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments:
We have ascribed a marginally higher P/B multiple of 0.85x (previously 0.8x) to SIA- ex SIAEC and we roll over our valuation to FY17. The higher P/B multiple is justified on the basis of sequential improvement in: 

 pax load factor, 
 the fact that SIA is projected to earn over a S$1b net profit in FY17, 
 attractive forward dividend yield of 5.8% and the fact that SIA traded at well over 1x P/B in 2010, when earnings breached S$1b.

arguments: pax load factor,

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: the fact that SIA is projected to earn over a S$1b net profit in FY17,

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Strong Sequential Improvement In SIA’s And Scoot’s Load Factors
arguments: attractive forward dividend yield of 5.8% and the fact that SIA traded at well over 1x P/B in 2010, when earnings breached S$1b.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: ■ SIA mainline passenger business hit by European weakness

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: ■ SilkAir and Scoot were the shining stars

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: ■ Tiger Airways privatisation is an important strategic move

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: ■ Other structural moves to yield dividends later

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: ■ Cyclical factors could improve

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: Although SIA’s 1H16 results disappointed, investors need not be overly pessimistic, as a cyclical upturn may yet arrive and structural reforms are being implemented.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: European passenger weakness, and the air freight slowdown were the key cyclical drags, but it would be unusual for the weakness to last beyond the next six months.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: Long-term initiatives like SilkAir’s and Scoot’s expansion are bearing fruit, while the privatisation of Tiger Airways would yield even more group-wide synergies.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: We stay Add as we see upside surprises given the depressed share price, with our target of S$12.83 still based on P/BV of 1.1x (average since 2001).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: In the past two quarters, the mainline carrier’s yield weakness was primarily due to weak European demand, which was not surprising given the continent’s especially weak business environment this year.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: The Australian market was strong despite the weak Australian dollar, which we attribute to capacity reductions by two Malaysian carriers.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: While US demand was good, North Asian competitors had added capacity which caused fare compression.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: Competition to Europe from Gulf carriers also added to the mix.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: In contrast, the intra-Asia market was stable, and SilkAir benefitted from an improved competitive standing after excessive regional LCC expansion in 2012-13 was partially reversed in 2014.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: Both SilkAir and Scoot saw significant 4-7% yoy unit cost reductions for 1HFY16 on the back of their 9-10% yoy ASK growth (which spread out fixed costs) and improved fleet efficiencies as their older aircraft were replaced with new ones.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: We view SIA’s move to privatise Tiger as being very beneficial against the small cost of doing so, particularly as SIA reallocates traffic rights across different airlines in the group to maximise revenue potential.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: Already, SIA and SilkAir have announced the transfer of several less-premium destinations to Scoot to improve profits. More will follow.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: SIA’s A350s which start delivery soon will improve profits on smaller European routes as they replace larger B777-300ERs. SIA’s recent order for seven ultra long-range A350s for 2018 delivery will enable it to compete for non-stop transpacific passengers and open up new direct US points.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: Premium economy, only introduced from August, is already seeing strong demand on the Kangaroo route, with impressive loads in the mid-80s.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: Its lounges and cabin products are also being refreshed to stay ahead of the competition.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: Erstwhile weak cargo demand is currently ramping up for the year-end peak season.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: We think European passenger demand may improve next year, as weak trading conditions cannot last forever.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Don’t be too pessimistic
arguments: With SIA’s shares trading at trough levels of 0.9x P/BV (1 s.d. below mean), downside risks have been reflected and the market is ready for upside surprise.
