title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: SHARE PRICE CATALYST

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: Aside from SilkAir, loads improved for parent airline and all subsidiaries. This is positive, given the tough operating conditions and depressed yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: Going forward, we estimate that unit cost will decline qoq due to lower fuel hedging losses and lead to higher profits, should load factors be sustained.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: Maintain HOLD. Target price: S$11.00. Suggested entry level: S$10.30.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: This is an improvement over September’s flat loads (0.0ppt), continuing the trend of improvement that started in July. The rise in October’s load factor was led by a 5.7ppt increase in loads to the South West Pacific region, which comprises about 20% of capacity. SIA also continued to rationalise capacity, with 1.8% reductions ytd.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: The load factor improvement to Europe (Oct: +0.3ppt vs Sep: -2.1ppt) suggests that SIA could have gained market share on some routes, but likely at the expense of lower yields. Even so, SIA’s exposure to Europe is substantial at 29% and hence the higher loads are operationally critical for the carrier.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: In addition, long-haul market America also fared well with a 1.8ppt improvement in pax loads.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: This does not come as a surprise as 3Q is a seasonally stronger quarter for cargo demand.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: Traffic rose 25.5%, outpacing capacity growth, which led to improved load factors (+2.8ppt). Comparatively, SilkAir’s load factor fell as its aggressive capacity expansion of 11% yoy was not completely absorbed by market demand.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: The higher loads for parent airline and subsidiaries are positive given fierce competition and depressed yields. Assuming pax loads and yields approximate that of 2QFY16, SIA should have been profitable in October.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: Going forward, pax yields are likely to be higher qoq due to a seasonally strong 3Q. Moreover, lower hedging losses should also lead to lower opex for the carrier.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: On balance, we believe that SIA should show increased profitability in the upcoming quarter should high load factors be sustained. We also do not expect a significant impact to earnings from the recent attacks in Paris. France accounts for about 3% of capacity but we do not expect significant demand destruction.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: The JV and partnership announced on 11 Nov involves cooperation and codesharing for key markets in Europe, Southeast Asia and Australia. This would enable SIA to expand its geographical reach into Europe via Lufthansa’s network in Frankfurt, Munich and Zurich.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: With the expanded network, SIA could position itself to compete with the Middle Eastern carriers and potentially establish new routes with higher yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: No change to our earnings estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: Maintain HOLD and S$11.00 target price. We continue to value SIA’s core business at 0.80x book value, ex-SIAEC. Suggested entry price is S$10.30.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Good Start To 3QFY16
arguments: Greater-than-expected pax yields and lower fuel costs.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Formed revenue-sharing partnership with Lufthansa
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Lufthansa have signed a wide-ranging partnership agreement to operate on a JV-basis, which means sharing of revenue on flights between Singapore and key Europe routes such as Frankfurt and Munich.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Formed revenue-sharing partnership with Lufthansa
arguments: The agreement will also see both airlines further their cooperation in key markets in Europe, Southeast Asia and Australia including coordination in schedules to improve connectivity and addition of more than 20 new codeshare routes.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Formed revenue-sharing partnership with Lufthansa
arguments: The agreement includes SIA’s subsidiary SilkAir, as well as Lufthansa’s subsidiaries Austrian Airlines and Swiss. Note that while some elements of the agreement will be introduced in the coming months, other elements are subjected to regulatory approvals and may be implemented progressively through CY16. Such alliance is not the first for Lufthansa as it already has JVs with other airlines such as ANA in the Germany-Japan market.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Formed revenue-sharing partnership with Lufthansa
arguments: In our view, we see this tie-up with Lufthansa positively and believe it could help SIA mitigate pressures from the fast-growing Gulf carriers.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Formed revenue-sharing partnership with Lufthansa
arguments: As this is still in its early stage, we prefer to wait as the two airlines execute their partnership agreement. Hence, we keep our forecasts unchanged and maintain HOLD on SIA with the same FV of S$11.45.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments: Highlights from the analyst briefing

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments: SIA mainline passenger business hit by European weakness

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments: SilkAir and Scoot were the shining stars

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments: Tiger Airways privatisation is an important strategic move

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments: More will follow.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments: Cyclical factors could improve

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
Although SIA’s 1H16 results disappointed, investors need not be
                                                overly pessimistic, as a cyclical upturn may yet arrive and structural
                                                reforms are being implemented.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
European passenger weakness, and the air freight slowdown were the key
                                                cyclical drags, but it would be unusual for the weakness to last beyond
                                                the next six months.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
Long-term initiatives like SilkAir’s and Scoot’s expansion
                                                are bearing fruit, while the privatisation of Tiger Airways would yield
                                                even more group-wide synergies.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
We lower EPS forecasts and reduce the target (to S$12.83),
                                                still based on P/BV of 1.1x (average since 2001) and rolled-over to
                                                end-CY16. We stay Add as we see upside surprises.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
SIA held a customary post-results analyst briefing last Friday, that
                                                lasted beyond the typical one hour, as management presented the merits
                                                of the voluntary offer for Tiger Airways’ shares, as well as
                                                discussed the present dynamics of the business.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
SIA commented that the mainline carrier’s yield weakness was
                                                primarily due to weak European demand, which was not surprising given
                                                the continent’s especially weak business environment this
                                                year.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
The Australian market was strong despite the weak Australian dollar,
                                                which we attribute to capacity reductions by two Malaysian
                                                carriers.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
While US demand was good, North Asian competitors had added capacity
                                                which caused fare compression.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments: Competition to Europe from Gulf carriers also added to the mix.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
In contrast, the intra-Asia market was stable, and SilkAir benefitted
                                                from an improved competitive standing after excessive regional LCC
                                                expansion in 2012-13 was partially reversed in 2014. Both SilkAir and
                                                Scoot saw significant 4-7% yoy unit cost reductions for 1HFY16 on the
                                                back of their 9-10% yoy ASK growth (which spread out fixed costs) and
                                                improved fleet efficiencies as their older aircraft were replaced with
                                                new ones.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
We view SIA’s move to privatise Tiger as being very beneficial
                                                against the small cost of doing so, particularly as SIA reallocates
                                                traffic rights across different airlines in the group to maximise
                                                revenue potential.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
Already, SIA and SilkAir have announced the transfer of several
                                                less-premium destinations to Scoot to improve profits.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
Other structural moves to yield dividends later SIA’s A350s
                                                which start delivery soon will improve profits on smaller European
                                                routes as they replace larger B777-300ERs. SIA’s recent order for
                                                seven ultra long-range A350s for 2018 delivery will enable it to compete
                                                for non-stop transpacific passengers and open up new direct US
                                                points.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
Premium economy, only introduced from August, is already seeing strong
                                                demand on the Kangaroo route, with impressive loads in the
                                                mid-80s.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
Its lounges and cabin products are also being refreshed to stay ahead
                                                of the competition.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
Erstwhile weak cargo demand is currently ramping up for the year-end
                                                peak season. We think European passenger demand may improve next year,
                                                as weak trading conditions cannot last forever.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Risks skewed to the upside
arguments:
With SIA’s shares trading at trough levels of 0.9x P/BV (1 s.d.
                                                below mean), downside risks have been reflected and the market is ready
                                                for upside surprise.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: 2QFY16 reported PATMI boosted by one-off dividend income

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: Privatising Tigerair helps in unlocking synergies

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: Expects fuel costs to drop further; maintain HOLD

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: Singapore Airlines’ (SIA) 2QFY16 core PATMI missed our expectations as it formed only 21.1% of our FY16 forecasts.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: Excluding Tigerair, 2QFY16 revenue declined 5.8% YoY to S$3.7b, mainly due to a 7.0% decline in revenue from the parent airline as a result of a 4.6% decline in passenger yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: Cargo yield also fell 9.4% despite higher freight carriage. If not for the 15.2% YoY decline in 2QFY16 fuel costs, total operating expenses would have been higher, driven mainly by higher aircraft lease rentals, costs to retrofit cabins for premium economy product, and aircraft maintenance and overhaul costs.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: Consequently, 2QFY16 reported PATMI jumped 135.0% to S$213.6m, but stripping out one-off dividend income of S$91.1m, 2QFY16 core PATMI came in at S$122.5m.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: For 1HFY16, core PATMI rose 161.6% YoY to S$213.7m, which formed only 36.8% of our FY16 forecasts.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: In our view, privatising Tigerair will benefit SIA over a longer-term horizon as it gives management flexibility and ability to accelerate the process to unlock synergies within the group to achieve cost savings and maximisation of revenue.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: Within SIA’s portfolio, we believe there are much more in terms of route rationalization that can be done between Scoot and Tigerair to capture interlining traffic. However, given current competitive landscape of the airline industry within the region, SIA’s traditional strategy of pursuing growth through its full service parent airline will not help.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: We believe pressure on passenger yields on its parent airline is likely to remain with the continued capacity expansion of the Gulf carriers, especially for the Europe routes.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: For 2HFY16, SIA is 50.7% hedged at an averaged hedged price of US$93/barrel. Management guided that the percentage hedged and average hedged price will decline with time as the more expensive hedges continue to expire.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: Incorporating 2QFY16 results and mixed outlook, we cut FY16F PATMI by 1.1% but raise FY17F PATMI by 4.3%.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Pressures on parent airline to stay
arguments: Consequently, our FV increases marginally to S$11.45 (prev: S$11.27). Maintain HOLD.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: WHAT’S NEW

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: STOCK IMPACT

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: EARNINGS REVISION/RISK

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: VALUATION/RECOMMENDATION

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: SHARE PRICE CATALYST

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: All eyes were on Tigerair, however, the issue very much remains on yields and fuel hedges.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: Pax yields declined to an all-time low in August but showed improvement in September.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: Meanwhile, SIA recognised S$569m in hedging losses in 1HFY16.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: With older fuel hedges rolling off, we believe fuel hedging losses could halve, resulting in improved profitability.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: Maintain HOLD but raise our target price to S$11.00. Preferred entry price: S$10.30.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: Conditional offer of S$0.41 per share for Tigerair is a 390% premium to Tigerair’s NAV as at end-Sep 15. SIA’s cost to acquire the remaining shares of Tigerair will amount to S$453m, excluding the offer for outstanding PCCS.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments:
From a financial perspective, we see little merit to the offer, given that SIA: 

 already has effective control of Tigerair, and 
 has about S$12.8b of capital commitments on its own and its cash holdings is S$4.9b, thus effectively an inefficient utilisation of resources.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: already has effective control of Tigerair, and

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: has about S$12.8b of capital commitments on its own and its cash holdings is S$4.9b, thus effectively an inefficient utilisation of resources.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: Pax yield fell 4.6% yoy, within expectations. Yields declined the most in August, and showed sequential improvement in September. The crux of the issue is to what extent yields can stabilise in the coming months. In 2HFY15, pax yields were relatively firm. On balance, we believe yields will decline by at least 5% in 2HFY16.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: Scoot’s losses had declined by 90% as overall operating costs declined sharply from greater fuel efficiency. SilkAir meanwhile benefitted from lower unit costs and higher yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: While we believe some of the aggressive price discounts are likely to end, given stability in fuel prices, we believe SIA’s ticket prices are still at a substantial premium to competitors. If economic environment continues to weaken, SIA’s ability to maintain yields will be further impacted even if fuel prices stabilise.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: 2QFY16’s improved earnings were also a reflection of higher load factors. We are unsure as to what extent SIA will be able to improve its utilisation. August’s load factor for example was flat yoy, compared to July’s and August’s 2.7ppt increase.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: SIA recognised S$569m in fuel hedging losses in 1HFY16. In 2H15, we believe this quantum will drop as existing fuel hedges are lower. For instance, SIA has hedged 50.7% of its 2HFY16 fuel requirements at US$93/bbl vs 55.4% hedged at US$104/bbl. Thus, if fuel prices remain unchanged from 2QFY16’s average, fuel hedging losses should be lowered by US$11/bbl and lead to an almost S$300m drop in fuel hedging losses hoh.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments:
We raise our FY16 net profit forecast by 133%, factoring in: 

 S$88m in incremental dividends, and 
 lower fuel hedging losses following SIA’s latest guidance on the quantum of fuel hedged.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: S$88m in incremental dividends, and

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: lower fuel hedging losses following SIA’s latest guidance on the quantum of fuel hedged.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: We also raise our FY17 net profit estimates by 90% after lowering our average jet fuel assumption from US$88/bbl to US$80/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: On balance, we see no reason for SIA to trade above book value.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: We believe our valuation is aggressive as we value the core airline business at 0.8x P/B despite ROE of under 5%.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: While ROE could be enhanced by increasing dividend payout, SIA’s capex commitments of S$12.8b over the next three years could limit dividend payouts.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: We continue to value SIA’s core business at 0.80x book value, ex-SIAEC.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Takeaways From Analysts’ Briefing
arguments: Higher-than-expected pax and cargo yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Highlights of 2QFY16 (quarter ended September 2015)

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Mainline carrier earnings dropped more than expected

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: SilkAir and Scoot performed very well

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: SIA Cargo narrowed losses despite poor market conditions

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Tiger Airways contributed losses to the group

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Near-term outlook mixed

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: SIA’s earnings underperformed our expectations as its 1HFY16 core net profit made up just 32% of our previous full-year forecast, vs. over 40% in the past three years.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: The mainline SIA suffered a bigger-than-expected fall in passenger yields due to aggressive competition, while unit costs did not decline as much as anticipated.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: On the bright side, SilkAir, Scoot and SIA Cargo delivered substantial improvement.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: We maintain our Add call, and leave our earnings forecasts and target price unchanged (at average P/BV since 2001 of 1.1x) pending today’s briefing.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: The SIA group delivered core net profit of S$198m in 2Q16, but this included unusually high dividends from “long-term investments”. Without this, core earnings would only have been S$107m, down 13% yoy on a like-for-like basis, despite low oil prices.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: For 1H16, core net profit without the dividend and without the compensation from Airbus and Boeing for delivery delays, would have been 47% lower yoy.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: SIA declared an interim 10 Scts DPS, up from 5 Scts last year.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Mainline SIA saw its core EBIT fall 28% yoy in 2Q16, and fall 43% for 1H16, excluding compensation for delivery delays. Its unit cost reduction was minimal despite jet fuel prices (inclusive of hedging losses) falling 27% yoy to US$90/bbl in 2Q16, as it saw higher maintenance and leasing costs, while the US$ appreciated 11% against the S$.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Mainline SIA also lowered its yields 4.6% to compete for passengers.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Finally, there was also a large, unexplained fall in ‘ancillary income’ .

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: In contrast, SilkAir and Scoot both delivered load factor increases, stable/higher yields, and sharply lower unit costs as a result of their fleet modernisation programmes. Hence, SilkAir saw significantly higher profits, while Scoot neared breakeven.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: SIA’s investment in, and expansion of, these two carriers is yielding fruit as they have a bright future.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Surprisingly, SIA Cargo managed to narrow its losses yoy despite poor operating conditions. Cargo yields dropped almost double-digit, as lower fuel costs were entirely passed through. Poor air freight demand also caused SIA Cargo to suffer a fall in loads.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Tigerair Singapore contributed S$10m in operating losses in 2Q16. It was only consolidated from Oct 2014 (3Q15).

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: SIA Engineering saw its profit contribution rise as it reduced expenses more quickly than the reduction in its revenue.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Mainline SIA’s monthly passenger yields continued to decline at its fastest pace this year, in the data released up to Sep. At the same time, SIA’s all-in fuel cost may decline 13% from US$94/bbl in 1H16, to as low as US$82/bbl in 2H16.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: SIA guided that advance passenger bookings for Oct-Dec are positive, but mainly boosted by promotional activities, suggesting a mixed outlook in the near future.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Mainline carrier disappoints
arguments: Separately, SilkAir and Scoot will likely continue to deliver strong improvements on a yoy basis.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: RESULTS

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: STOCK IMPACT

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: EARNINGS REVISION/RISK

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: VALUATION/RECOMMENDATION

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: SHARE PRICE CATALYST

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: An S$88m rise in dividend income boosted bottom line, without which core earnings would have been below expectations.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: SIA also recognised some S$300m in fuel hedging losses during the period.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: Going into 2HFY16, we believe SIA’s fuel and non-fuel costs will decline and aid profitability.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: We will provide further updates pending an analyst meeting.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: Maintain HOLD. Target price: S$10.70. Entry price: S$10.30.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: Included in 2QFY16 results was an S$91.1m gain (previously S$3.0m) from long-term investments, without which PBT would have been 17% below our estimate. The differential also led to net profit coming in 9% and 20% below our and consensus’ expectations respectively.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: SIA continued to receive compensation of S$10.7m from aircraft delivery slots but this was substantially lower than the S$110.1m in 1QFY16. SIA declared a higher interim dividend of 10 cents (2QFY15: 5 cents).

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: Book value increased 2% yoy for the quarter.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: Unit cost fell by lesser than our estimate of a 6% decline, mainly due to higher maintenance costs, aircraft rental costs and handling charges which offset fuel cost savings.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: This was due to a steep reduction in proceeds from aircraft sales in the current quarter, but operating cash flow rose 24% yoy.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: In 2QFY16, SIA hedged 55.4% of its fuel requirements at US$104/bbl. Into-plane fuel cost however averaged US$67/bbl. The differential along with MTM losses led to the steep hedging losses. The cumulative hedging losses amounted to S$569m in 1HFY16.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: For 2HFY16, SIA guided it had hedged 50.7% of its fuel requirements at US$93/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: Some S$50m of the increase was from higher maintenance cost (+32.1% yoy), which SIA attributed to retrofitting premium economy seats. Aircraft rentals also rose by S$55m (+29.9% yoy) presumably due to higher aircraft leases. Going forward, we believe maintenance costs will normalise.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: This is due to fuel hedges at lower levels, which on its own will provide much of the likely hoh improvement in earnings. We have yet to include that in our net profit estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: While the fall in pax yields was within our expectations, SIA has also indicated that weaker bellyhold and other incidental revenue also contributed to lower revenue. SIA continues to guide on weak yields and cautions on both passenger and cargo traffic.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: No change to our net profit estimates, pending an analyst briefing today.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: We continue to value SIA’s core business at 0.80x book value, ex-SIAEC. Suggested entry price is S$10.30.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - 2QFY16 ~ Earnings Below Expectations But Scope For Improvement
arguments: Higher-than-expected pax and cargo yields.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: WHAT’S NEW

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: ESSENTIALS

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: ASSUMPTION CHANGES

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: RISKS

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: We expect SIA to report a 52% yoy rise in 2QFY16 net profit due to improved profitability at the parent airline.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: For SIAEC, we are expecting a 10% yoy rise in 2QFY16 operating profit due to a weak base and a likely increase in A380-related “C” checks.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: Meanwhile, SATS is expected to register an 18% yoy increase in 2QFY16 net profit due to improved gateway services margin and cost savings.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: Maintain MARKET WEIGHT.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: The parent airline is expected to report an operating profit of S$180.8m, driven by higher pax load and lower fuel costs but offset partially by lower pax yield. We have estimated a 4.6% yoy decline in pax yields and essentially assumed the pace of decline has continued from that in May-Jun 15. Every 0.1 S cent change from our base assumption will impact the parent airline’s operating profit and group net profit by S$25m and S$20m respectively.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: Meanwhile, existing fuel hedges are expected to lead to more than S$200m fuel hedging losses for the period.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: Overall, we expect SIA to declare an unchanged interim dividend of 5 cents/share.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: In the previous down cycle, yields only bottomed out two quarters after jet fuel prices bottomed out. A similar scenario could pan out over the next two quarters.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: SIAEC could see higher airframe revenue due to “C” checks on SIA’s A380 aircraft. We are however doubtful of a meaningful improvement in engine maintenance revenue, which declined by almost 42% in the previous quarter.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: We expect a 1 S cent decline in interim dividend to 5 S cents/share.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: Higher unit services and unit meals are expected to lead to a small revenue growth, while lower raw material costs and licensing fees are expected to boost operating profit. On the revenue front, SATS had resumed handling Jetstar Asia’s gateway operations from Jul 15, which we believe accounted for most of the increase in unit services.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: On the cost front, raw material costs are likely to have declined in line with the lower commodity prices, while rebates announced by Changi Airport is likely to lead to lower opex.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: We estimate its interim dividend is likely to remain unchanged at 5 S cents/share.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: TFK secured a S$325m long-term contract from Delta Airlines, which should start contributing in 2HFY16. We reckon TFK was operating close to breakeven level in previous quarters and that the Delta contract will boost operating profit.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: The extent of yield decline and quantum of fuel hedges will be the key focus areas. If the decline in yield is less than expected due to better pricing or a weaker Singapore dollar, it will have positive ramifications for the remaining quarters.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: SIAEC will be hosting an analyst briefing. We will seek greater clarity on the trend for third-party maintenance and engine checks. SIAEC cut interim and final dividends in FY15.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: ASP for gateway services and inflight catering will be key focus areas. If yields stabilise, particularly for gateway services, that will hold scope for higher margins. We would also seek greater clarity on the increase in unit services and meals. Associate income typically accounts for 15-20% of pre-tax profit. A qoq decline could suggest that associates were impacted by lower cargo handled or translation losses.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: No change to assumptions.

title: Aviation Singapore  - Earnings Preview For SIA, SIAEC And SATS
arguments: Weaker-than-expected yields.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments: 2QFY16 results on 5 Nov. Expect core net PATAMI of SGD169m (+197% YoY, +85% QoQ).

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments: Cut FY16-18 EPS by 9-11% after imputing revised lower traffic growth & the latest jet-fuel & USD/SGD assumptions.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments: Downgrade to HOLD from BUY due to limited upside and no immediate catalyst. TP marginally lowered to SGD11.80.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments: We downgrade the share in light of persistent soft yield environment and management’s plans to taper down future growth capacity plans. Otherwise, 2QFY16 operating statistics were in line with our expectations.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments: System traffic growth rose 11.2% YoY and load factor, 1.9ppt YoY to 70.8%. This was its highest load factor since 2002.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments: Load factor is impressive, but this came at the expense of lower yields as competitors cut prices to gain market share and loads. SIA has to reciprocate by dropping its fares but is saddled with expensive fuel hedges: 55% of its fuel in 2QFY16 had been fixed at USD104/bbl vs an average market price of USD66/bbl.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments: We cut FY16-18 EPS by 11.4%/8.5%/10.5% after filtering revenue generated from aircraft slot trades which we deem non-recurring.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments: We also adjust capacity-growth assumptions based on management’s inputs and our yield, jet-fuel and USD/SGD assumptions.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments: Downgrade to HOLD from BUY with a lower TP of SGD11.80 from SGD11.85, after revising earnings. Our fair value is based on an unchanged 1.0x FY17 P/BV, its 10-year mean.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
Group - parent airline, Silk Air, Scoot and Tigerair - passenger load factor
improved 1.9ppts YoY to 83.1% in 2QFY16. This was its best quarterly load
factor since it started publishing the information. Traffic growth was flat
as ASK shrank 0.1% YoY. From this, we infer that this was the second year
that the group’s capacity has not grown. Management says it will inject
capacity growth in CY2016, supported by incoming fleet deployment.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
The cargo market was less buoyant as its load factor shrank 1.7ppts YoY to
60.3%. Load factor has been languishing at its 5-year low mark since Apr
2015. Cargo capacity grew 2.6% YoY in 2QFY16. Management pointed to a
weak air-freight industry that is suffering from overcapacity.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
Almost all the geographical segments exhibited an exceptional Jul-Aug
2015 before easing in Sep 2015. We are not concerned by the drop in Sep
2015 load factors as it coincided with flight frequency addition. The
standouts are the Australasia and European sectors, which are achieving
above 90% load factors. This momentum should continue into 2HFY16 and
deliver even better YoY comparisons as 2HFY15 was saddled by specific
challenges on the Southeast and North Asian routes.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
Firstly, we filter the SGD110m compensation received in 1QFY16 for the
release of seven aircraft delivery slots meant for FY18-19 as we deem this
as non-recurring income ― this information was only revealed during the
1QFY16 analyst briefing.
We use management’s latest guidance on capacity deployment, which will
shrink marginally.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
Overall yields have been tweaked lower to reflect
current industry trends. Our fuel-price assumptions have taken into
account SIA’s latest fuel hedges. Based on these assumptions, we forecast
a core net PATAMI of SGD650.3m (+314% YoY). This is 11.4% lower than our
previous estimate of SGD734.3m.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
The SGD has weakened against the USD
and this has caused many USD-denominated costs to rise in SGD terms.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
Again we use management’s latest guidance on capacity growth and use
our latest house USD/SGD forex rate. We taper down our yield assumption
to reflect the current weak yield environment. Our fuel-price assumptions
have taken into account SIA’s latest fuel hedges. Based on these
assumptions, we forecast a core net PATAMI of SGD808.1m (+24.3% YoY).
This is 8.5% lower than our previous estimate of SGD828.1m.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
We use management’s latest guidance on fleet deployment to ascertain
capacity growth. We expect the high number of aircraft deployment to
accelerate traffic growth to 5.0%. We assume an average jet fuel price of
USD100/bbl, and this will be adjusted as necessary. Based on these
assumptions, we forecast a core net PATAMI of SGD879.8m (+8.9% YoY).
This is 10.5% lower than our previous estimate of SGD983.3m.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
Our revised target price is SGD11.80, down marginally from SGD11.85, on
the back of the downward earnings revisions.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
Our revised TP is still pegged
to 1x FY17 P/BV, which is close to its long-term mean of 0.98x. This should
be a good floor-price indicator for the airline as the company will produce
healthy earnings and strong balance sheet.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
The stock price has re-rated since our upgrade on 18 Aug. As there is
limited upside potential to our fair value estimate, downgrade to HOLD
from BUY.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
SIA plans to re-launch the world’s longest non-stop flight from Singapore to
New York, and Singapore to Los Angeles as well as other points in the US by
2018. SIA will utilize the latest generation Airbus A350-900 ultra-long-haul
(ULH) aircraft that is capable of flying up to 8,700nm.
SIA previously had daily services to New York and Los Angeles, which were
exceptionally popular among customers but it was discontinued in 2013 as
it was unfeasible due to high fuel prices. SIA is sanguine that the new
generation A350-900 ULH has superior cost economics and ensures
profitable operations.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
We are neutral on this announcement as it is many
years away and have no financial implication in the short term.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
Scoot will operate the Singapore to Jeddah (Saudi Arabia) services from 1
May 2016, effectively taking the route over from SIA. This is to optimize
the landing slots as Scoot’s Boeing 787-8 aircraft has 335 seats as opposed
to SIA’s Airbus A330-300’s 285 seats (+17.5% more seats). Moreover, the
route caters specifically to religious pilgrims whom sole focus is for lower
cost of travel rather than premium services.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
This is a wise decision by management to right-fit the product profile to
passenger demand. However, there is brand-equity erosion on the part of
SAI as this route is a major void in the airline’s ambition to become a
globally connected player. Jeddah is a key aviation destination with over
70 airlines servicing the route and direct global connectivity to more than
200 destinations.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
All things considered, we believe the commercial decision by management
to replace SIA flight with Scoot is the best trade off.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
Scoot and Tigerair (56%-owned subsidiary; Not Rated) will expand their cooperation
and jointly manage the Singapore to Guangzhou (China) route.
Both airlines will operate twice-daily services, and this is envisaged to
better match capacity to demand.

title: Singapore Airlines  - 2QFY16 ~ D/G to HOLD, lacks catalyst
arguments:
This tie-up reinforces our view that Tigerair will eventually be taken
private by the Group. We believe there will be further co-operation and
tie-ups as it is inevitable to behave as part of the Group. Therefore, it
would be much easier on the Group to privatise Tigerair to absolve itself
from making countless regulatory announcements and due considerations.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: SHARE PRICE CATALYST

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: Despite flat performance for September, overall pax loads for 2QFY16 have improved, supported by both capacity reductions and traffic growth.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: Parent airline SIA is expected to be in the black for the quarter, unless pax yields decline by more than 9% (1QFY15 -2%). SIA is expected to release its interim results on 5 Nov 15 and we will provide an earnings preview shortly.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: Maintain HOLD. Target price: S$10.70. Entry price: S$9.60.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: SIA’s 2QFY16 load factors improved 1.8ppt; pace of improvement tapers off in Sep 15. The improvement was mainly aided by capacity reductions (-1.6%). Overall, 2QFY16’s pax traffic was flat yoy, with September reversing the preceding months’ upward trend. This lacklustre traffic growth comes despite promotional activities and the summer travel demand.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: Pax loads to key markets Europe and US reversed from two consecutive months of gains to a decline in September. The 2.1ppt and 1.4ppt decline in loads to Europe and the US in Sep 15 could be due to recent capacity additions by Qatar at Changi.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: Improved load factor likely to lead SIA into black in 2QFY16. In the previous period, SIA’s parent operations was S$2m in the red, excluding S$110m in slot compensation. In the current period, SIA’s pax load factor is 7.4ppt higher qoq. Thus, unless SIA’s pax yield declines by more than 9% qoq, the parent airline is likely to be profitable in the current quarter.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: Cargo traffic improved in Sep 15 with stronger loads to the South West Pacific market (+9.0%), but expected to continue to post a loss in 2QFY16. Cargo loads improved to South West Pacific, Asia and Africa, despite a decline to the Europe and US markets. The stronger loads are likely to be IT-related shipments, such as iPhones and electronic gadgets. However, we reckon the improvement comes on the back of reduced cargo yields. With cargo load factors still 0.8ppt lower than in 1QFY16 (61.1%), we expect cargo operations to continue to be in the red.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: 2Q is a seasonally stronger period compared with 1Q and thus improved profitability should not come as a surprise. Still, we expect yields to continue to decline yoy and qoq for 2QFY16 due to promotional activities and changing macro landscape. As of Sep 15, SIA has guided that “promotional activities will continue in relevant markets”.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: Premium traffic is an integral part of SIA’s business, accounting for more than one-third of revenue historically. We believe that front-end ticket pricing would have been lowered for 2QFY16, in view of cyclical weakness in the financial and O&G sectors.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: The flights would commence in 2018 with the more fuel efficient A350-900ULR. SIA previously operated flights to the US on A340s that were too costly, exiting in late-13. We view this as a strategic move to: a) tap on the North American long-haul market which has fewer competitors and no Gulf presence, and b) lower the risk of customers switching to other carriers that operate services to the US.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: There is no change to our FY16 net profit estimates.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: Maintain HOLD and S$10.70 target price.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: We continue to value SIA’s core business at 0.80x book value, ex-SIAEC. Suggested entry price is S$9.60.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: Lower fuel hedges.

title: Singapore Airlines  - Weak September Loads, But Still A Qoq Improvement
arguments: Strengthening US dollar against the Singapore dollar.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - To re-launch direct flights between Singapore and U.S.
arguments: Singapore Airlines (SIA) announced last evening that it has signed an agreement to be the launch customer for a new ultra-long-range variant of the Airbus A350 aircraft (i.e. A35-900ULR). This agreement will lift SIA’s total number of firm order for A350s to 67, of which seven will be upgraded to the A350-900ULR, plus 16 purchase options.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - To re-launch direct flights between Singapore and U.S.
arguments: The first A350-900 is expected to be delivered in early-2016 while the first A350- 900ULR is scheduled for delivery in 2018. The delivery of A350-900ULR in 2018 will enable SIA, in a commercially viable manner, to re-launch the world’s longest non-stop flights, between Singapore and both Los Angeles and New York.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - To re-launch direct flights between Singapore and U.S.
arguments: Non-stop flights between Singapore and additional points in the U.S. are also under consideration.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - To re-launch direct flights between Singapore and U.S.
arguments: In our view, this is certainly positive for SIA in the longer-term to regain market share of passenger traffic between Singapore and U.S., which was lost when SIA stopped such direct services since 2013. However, in the near to medium-term, we believe Gulf carriers continue to be a significant threat with aggressive expansion plans and we see pressures ahead on both yields and loads. Hence, we keep our forecasts unchanged for now.

title: Singapore Airlines SIA  - To re-launch direct flights between Singapore and U.S.
arguments: Maintain HOLD rating on SIA with FV of S$11.27.

arguments: Broad-based Improvement In SIA And SilkAir Load Factors

arguments: Yields have fallen considerably since May especially on transpacific and European routes whilst regional short-haul routes are stable.

title: Maybank Kim Eng 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Singapore Airlines SIA - 1Q16 Results. Reality Check. Maintain HOLD.
arguments: Cargo yields remain lacklustre due to industry overcapacity.

title: Maybank Kim Eng 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Singapore Airlines SIA - 1Q16 Results. Reality Check. Maintain HOLD.
arguments: Management has also reduced aircraft induction numbers for FY18- 19 suggesting that the headwinds are structural.

title: Maybank Kim Eng 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Singapore Airlines SIA - 1Q16 Results. Reality Check. Maintain HOLD.
arguments: SIA is struggling to nestle its space in the industry. Its business strategy to focus on premium business is at odds with the increasingly budget-centric profile of Southeast Asian passengers.

title: Maybank Kim Eng 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Singapore Airlines SIA - 1Q16 Results. Reality Check. Maintain HOLD.
arguments: Regional competitors have also stepped up its game and are serious contenders.

title: Maybank Kim Eng 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Singapore Airlines SIA - 1Q16 Results. Reality Check. Maintain HOLD.
arguments: Management is aware of these predicaments but is adamant that its strategy will set itself apart from the others.

title: Maybank Kim Eng 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Singapore Airlines SIA - 1Q16 Results. Reality Check. Maintain HOLD.
arguments: The results however points to the contrary: the parent airline’s route network has shrunk by 12% from the peak in 2009 and its passenger carried shrunk by 2% from the peak in 2007.

title: Maybank Kim Eng 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Singapore Airlines SIA - 1Q16 Results. Reality Check. Maintain HOLD.
arguments: SIA is clearly not a growth story and the investment objective is a play on the low fuel price environment and to cash in on dividends.

title: Maybank Kim Eng 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Singapore Airlines SIA - 1Q16 Results. Reality Check. Maintain HOLD.
arguments: We cut our FY16-18 earnings by 4.8%/6.4%/6.3% as we impute lower load factor to reflect current trends.

title: Maybank Kim Eng 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines SIA  - Singapore Airlines SIA - 1Q16 Results. Reality Check. Maintain HOLD.
arguments: Our target price has been revised down to SGD11.85 (from SGD12.40) based on 1.0x FY17 P/BV, and the stock remains a HOLD.

title: UOB Kay Hian 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Takeaways From Analyst Briefing on 1Q16 Results. Maintain SELL.

title: UOB Kay Hian 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Takeaways From Analyst Briefing on 1Q16 Results. Maintain SELL.

title: UOB Kay Hian 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Takeaways From Analyst Briefing on 1Q16 Results. Maintain SELL.
arguments: A drop towards S$10.00 or 0.73x P/B is not unforeseeable, but that could attract value investors.

title: UOB Kay Hian 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Takeaways From Analyst Briefing on 1Q16 Results. Maintain SELL.
arguments: This contrasts with that of the previous two quarters, which saw a steady increase.

title: UOB Kay Hian 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Takeaways From Analyst Briefing on 1Q16 Results. Maintain SELL.

title: UOB Kay Hian 2015-08-03: Singapore Airlines (SIA)  - Singapore Airlines (SIA) - Takeaways From Analyst Briefing on 1Q16 Results. Maintain SELL.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: What Happened

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: What We Think

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: What You Should Do

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: Predictably, SIA’s share price weakened after its 1Q results indicated that yields and loads were under pressure.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: But with the share price trading at close to S$10.60, which is at its support of 0.9x P/BV, or 1 s.d. below the average P/BV mean since 2001 of 1.1x, the downside is limited, and this could now be a good opportunity to accumulate.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: Our target is set at the P/BV mean and near-term upside catalysts include a lower price of jet fuel from 2H onwards, while medium-term catalysts include product retrofits and introduction of premium economy from Aug which should improve the yield mix, and fleet replacements that help lower unit costs.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: We maintain Add, but lower our FY16-18 forecasts 11-16% and reduce our target price (from S$12.97 to S$12.89) accordingly.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: At its analyst meeting, SIA highlighted that its monthly yields were showing pressures on a yoy as well as on a month-on-month basis (Figure 2), primarily on services to the US and Europe, reflecting aggressive capacity expansion by competitors.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: Passenger load factors also saw softness; despite SIA mainline reducing ASK capacity by 2.4% yoy during 1QFY15, RPK demand fell 4.2% yoy.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: Business class demand fell by more than economy class demand, leading to a negative mix effect which also weakened average yields.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: Services within ASEAN, and to Australia, had been less affected by yield pressures this time around, and SilkAir’s yields still managed a small 0.8% yoy increase while increasing capacity 7.2%.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: In contrast to SIA mainline, SilkAir’s PLF rose 0.6% pts yoy.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: The weakness in yields look likely to continue for the rest of the year and our previous SIA mainline yield forecast of 11.09 Scts/RPK for FY16 is now revised down to 10.98 Scts, down 2% from 11.20 Scts in FY15, and lower than even the 11.10 Scts achieved during FY14.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: There is no need to be overly pessimistic on SIA, especially at the current share price.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: Weak long-haul yields are a result of not just competition, but also the weak trade volume growth this year which tends to influence the level of long-haul business-related travel.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: We forecast a rebound in trade volumes next year that should help boost air travel demand. Also, fuel prices will finally decline more significantly for SIA in 2H to US$80/bbl, from US$94 in 1H, which could lift hoh earnings by an incremental S$365m.

title: CIMB Securities 2015-08-02: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Lower fuel prices to offer relief. Maintain ADD.
arguments: Not to mention that the 2H is the seasonal summer peak to Europe as well as the year-end school and Christmas holidays in Singapore.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: SIA fell into a core net loss of S$25m during 1QFY16, its first quarterly loss since 2009, underperforming our full-year profit forecast of S$721m, on yield weakness at SIA mainline and SIA Cargo due to strong competition to US and Europe and weak global trade growth.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: We maintain Add as we expect SIA to post better results in the 2H after it uses up most of its expensive legacy fuel hedges in the 1H.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: Medium-term catalysts include the introduction of premium economy from August, and cabin retrofits on the 777-300ERs that should improve the yield mix, and fleet replacements that should lower unit operating costs.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: We cut our EPS forecasts 8-26% on lower yield assumptions, and cut our target price to S$12.97 (from S$13.05), still based on 1.1x CY15 P/BV (average since 2001).

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: SIA reported a net profit of S$91m, but this included S$110m in compensation from Airbus for agreeing to give up seven slots out of its 70-strong A350 order, without which SIA would have suffered a core net loss of S$25m.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: This is SIA’s first quarterly core loss since 2009, and the unpleasant surprise was due to a 1.8% yoy yield decline at SIA mainline after two consecutive quarters of yield improvement, and an acceleration of the cargo yield decline to 7.6%.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: Weak trade volumes to Europe and the US likely hit passenger and cargo demand and exacerbated the competition and oversupply.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: While SilkAir did better than last year, and SIA Cargo and Scoot narrowed their losses, these did not compensate sufficiently for the drop in SIA mainline’s earnings.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: While revenue metrics will likely remain under pressure for the rest of the year, we highlight that SIA did not enjoy the full benefits of the low oil price during the 1Q, as 58.5% was hedged at US$110/bbl of jet.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: As a result, we estimate that SIA’s post-hedging fuel price fell only 20% yoy to US$96/bbl during 1Q16, against a 37.4% yoy drop in the spot price of jet to US$73/bbl.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: For the 2Q, SIA will remain highly hedged at 55.4% of consumption at US$104/bbl, but for 2H15, SIA will only be 32% hedged at around the same price.

title: CIMB Research 2015-07-30: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Look to 2H16 for better earnings. Maintain ADD.
arguments: Buying opportunity could emerge SIA’s share price could see pressure today, but anything below S$10.60 would be a good entry point, as SIA usually finds support at 0.9x P/BV, or 1 s.d. below the average P/BV mean since 2001 of 1.1x.

title: UOB Kay Hian Research 2015-07-01: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Maintain HOLD, lower target price to S$11.60 amid increased competition from Qatar Airways
arguments: Singapore Airlines’ (SIA) overall pax load factor fell 1.3ppt in 2MFY16 (Mar-Apr 15), with pax load factor to Europe declining by an average of 5.6ppt.

title: UOB Kay Hian Research 2015-07-01: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Maintain HOLD, lower target price to S$11.60 amid increased competition from Qatar Airways
arguments: Europe accounts for 28% of SIA’s (parent airline) capacity and is also a key market for business travels. The decline in Europe’s load factor could be due to Qatar Airways’ introduction of the new Airbus A350 aircraft on 11 May. Qatar Airways is also increasing its flight frequency to Doha to thrice weekly, from twice weekly, by August.

title: UOB Kay Hian Research 2015-07-01: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Maintain HOLD, lower target price to S$11.60 amid increased competition from Qatar Airways
arguments: According to the Centre for Asia Pacific Aviation, this will result in a 67% rise in Qatar Airways’ capacity out of Singapore.

title: UOB Kay Hian Research 2015-07-01: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Maintain HOLD, lower target price to S$11.60 amid increased competition from Qatar Airways

title: UOB Kay Hian Research 2015-07-01: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Maintain HOLD, lower target price to S$11.60 amid increased competition from Qatar Airways

title: UOB Kay Hian Research 2015-07-01: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Maintain HOLD, lower target price to S$11.60 amid increased competition from Qatar Airways
arguments: We cut our FY16 net profit forecast by 24%. Our net profit estimate is now 5% lower than consensus. Aside from yields and load factor, the primary swing factor will be fuel prices but the impact will not be significant as SIA has already hedged 55% of fuel requirements for the year.

title: UOB Kay Hian Research 2015-07-01: Singapore Airlines  - Singapore Airlines - Maintain HOLD, lower target price to S$11.60 amid increased competition from Qatar Airways
